text:
Wow, look no further for THE BEST oatmeal raisin cookie recipe.  I've tried 3 from this website and this one is the best- by a landslide.  Husband said it was the best oatmeal cookies he ever ate, and his mom makes this for her speciality, and my cookies came out better.  This is moist, chewy and perfectly sweet.  I followed other's advice and used all butter, which gave a fantastic buttery flavor and this stayed moist for a good 3 days (maybe longer, don't know cuz it never lasts that long in our house).  Just keep it in an airtight container.  And definitely watch your cooking time.  9 minutes was perfect, 10 min. gave it more color and add more crispness to the edges. I like mine soft and moist and this gives it all--look no futher folks!

These were very tasty cookies, I added another half teaspoon of cinnamon, a half teasoppon of nutmeg, and a 1/4 teaspoon of ginger.  I also used all butter.  I only left them in the oven for about 8 or 9 minutes so they would stay chewy after they cooled.  when I left them in for 12 minutes they were hard as a rock when they cooled off!

text:
i've made this recipe dozens of times since I first found it on Allrecipes. This is not the same recipe as the Quaker Oat cannister. That is the recipe I use to make. I double checked. Of course there are similarities, butter, sugar, oatmeal, etc. What Beth changes makes all the difference. The use of butter flavored shortening gives moistness and the cloves give great flavor.  These are far superior to the recipe on the oatmeal box. They are the most delicious cookies. They have just the right amount of spice and crispy moistness. I would definitely use butter and not margarine. The taste is not the same adn studies are now showing margarine is no healthier than butter. Thank you so much for this wonderful recipe, Beth. If you can come up with this great recipe, you should become a cookbook writer.

text:
Oh. My. God.  These cookies are delicious!  I did make a few changes though.  I didn't have butter-flavored shortening, so I just used regular shortening and added 1/2 tsp of butter flavoring.  Also, a soaked the raisins in hot water first to plump them up, substituted allspice for the cloves, and dumped in a package of instant vanilla pudding to make the cookies moister.  The result?  One fabulous cookie!

BETH!!  I NEED HELP!!  YOUR RECIPE IS AMAZING..BUT I THINK I MESSED IT UP!!  I made the recipe exactly how the instructions say except I used all butter and no shortening like the others.  I also uses golden raisins.  When my cookies came out they were soft and perfect but they never HARDENED...this was to the point that they all broke apart and fell through the cracks of my cooling rack.  I mean, I love soft cookies, don't get me wrong, but you couldn't even pick these up without them falling apart.  It was almost like they didn't cook.  I was also baking them for well over the time suggested (13-15 minutes).  When I tried to salvage them into a container they formed into this big DELICIOUS block of oatmeal mess!  The only thing I can think of is that I put the dough in the fridge prior to baking them for about an hour because I had to run out.  Is that the problem??  I didn't know that this could make a difference.  Is it possible that my eggs or flour or something was too old or maybe bad?  I can't imagine that, but at this point I am desperate!  The cookies were seriously amazing (hence the 5 stars), and I want to make them again, but I need them to hold their shape and somewhat harden!  Please please will someone help me?  Thank you in advance!

text:
I make awesome cookies, but I never had a good oatmeal raisin recipe. This one is it!  I used all butter flavored Crisco instead of using any butter (butter tends to burn in cookies).  I also soaked my raisins in warm water for 10 minutes before I added them to the dough.  Use the convection feature on your oven (If you have one).  Never grease or spray the pan (causes bottoms to burn).  Wipe the tray off between batches.  These cookies were soft and chewy with fabulous flavor!

text:
THE BEST cookie I have EVER tasted! I actually made an oatmeal mix for a trip I was going on that used cloves and cinnamon just like this recipe. I ended up not liking the oatmeal but didn't want to waste it, and when I came accross this recipe I was thrilled that it used the same ingredients! So I ended up making this cookie without changing anything, except using 1 cup of butter.  BUT, my oatmeal recipe did have 1 1/3 cups dry milk powder in it and I thought it might alter the cookies a little, but they turned out UNBELIEVABLE!!!!! So basically I doubled the cookie recipe, used all butter, and had 1 1/3 cups dry milk powder mixed in also!! THEY TURNED OUT SOOOO DELICIOUS!!!! I have DEFINATELY found my favorite oatmeal cookie recipe! I baked for 11 minutes each, and saw melted butter on the top when I took them out, but when they cooled overnight they ended up nice and chewy in the morning. TASTE LIKE BAKERY STYLE!! EVEN BETTER!! MMMMMMM I would give 100 STARS!!!!

text:
This recipe came out absolutely wonderful!! My parents liked the cookies a lot. I did make a few changes after reading some of the reviews: 
1)	Soaked the raisins in hot water for about 10 mins and rolled them in flour before adding it to the cookie mix
2)	I used all brown sugar instead of white and brown and the sweetness was perfect (for my family)
3)	Finally, (and this might be helpful for those people who find theirs runny) after finishing making the cookie mix, I put it in the refrigerator for about 30 mins. (cleaned up until then) and then I dropped a tsp mix on the cookie sheet and baked for 12 mins. The rest was the same…gotta try it out those of you who haven’t!

text:
This is the cookie that comes to mind when you think of oatmeal cookies. Sweet and mildly spicy, chewy and tender, with lots of raisins. The perfect comfort food. Why bother with any other oatmeal cookie recipe? Look no further - this is the real deal. Edited to add: It's true that this is not an original recipe. It's the old Quaker Oats recipe with only the addition of cloves. It's still arguably the best. It's certainly the best I've tried in over 46 years of baking, many of those years spent professionally! Perfect texture with the requisite chewiness and flavor. The addition of cloves kicks up the spiciness that is usually associated with a hearty, home made oatmeal raisin cookie. For those whose cookies came out too flat, adding 1-2 Tb flour will usually alleviate that problem. Just be aware that the cookie might be a tad denser as a result. For those who had trouble removing from the cookie sheet, use either parchment or foil (shiny side DOWN, and scoop the dough onto the dull side.) They will release after they are cool easily.

text:
I wish i could give this more stars! this was an excellent recipe. I read quite a few reviews and combined some of the modifications for a wonderful recipe :) here is what i did. i did not have ground cloves, instead I used 
1 1/2 tsp of cinnamon and 1/2 tsp each of nutmeg and allspice. i used all butter instead of the butter/shortening combo and they came out very moist and delicious. i also  added chopped walnuts and soaked the raisins in hot water to make more plump. to top off, i used the brown butter cinnamon glaze as suggested by another user and these were perfect. needless to say,I'll be making another batch later on!  thanks for the post :)

This has become a regular in the house (usually bake them twice a week).  The kids (aged 4, 3, and even the 2-year old) really love them, my husband raves about them (he's not a cookie lover, by the way) and practically anybody who'd tasted them. text:
Hubs’ birthday is tomorrow and he requested I make both chocolate chip and oatmeal cookies for him to take to work for his birthday treat.  When I mentioned this particular recipe, with its unusual addition of cloves, he said he’d prefer them without because cloves are for ham.  He reluctantly agreed to let me give it a try.  So I did, with the cloves and using half butter, half regular shortening (I tried the butter-flavored once, long ago and didn’t like it).  Both of us loved them.  The cloves are barely noticeable, just serving to give a bland, boring oatmeal cookie a little kick of distinction.

text:
Thanks for the recipe =) I modified it to make it a bit for a healthier flair: in place of the shortening, I added 1/2 cup of canned pumpkin; in place of 1 1/2 cups of all-purpose flour, I used 1 cup of whole wheat flour and 1/2 cup of all-purpose flour; in place of just 1 cup of raisins, I mixed in 1/2 cup of chopped apples, 1/4 cup of golden raisins (soaked in warm water first) and 1/2 cup of sugar-free chocolate covered raisins (I had to add chocolate in there somehow!) YUM!! I had to bake my cookies for about 12-13 minutes.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are the perfect oatmeal raisin cookie.  It is good to use the shortening with the butter because it keeps the cookies from spreading out and getting too thin or crisp.  Be sure not to soften your butter too much either, as this, too, will cause spreading.  I lined my baking sheets with wax paper first so they wouldn't stick, but also so I didn't have to grease, which, like so many other things, will lead to spreading.  I am only saying this because it seems to be the number one problem in baking, and with these tips, your cookies will come out perfectly.  I doubled the cinnamon, and I plumped my raisin by covering them in hot water for a few minutes and draining well before adding to the batter.  You can't fail with this recipe, and the cloves only makes it more seasonal tasting.  Enjoy!

Mmmm, very good!  I made a few changes to try to make them a bit healthier.  I used 1/2 cup whole wheat flour, added some flaxseed, and used butter instead of shortening (just because shortening grosses me out!).  I also added more raisins than called for, and added a few chocolate chips.  I baked these for 10 minutes on convection at 325.  They turned out great!!

text:
This is the perfect holiday cookie recipe. After eating a few of these cookies, I found that I had gained a new inner-personal sense of joy and accomplishment.  I spent several frustrating years trying to bake a decent cookie, only to have other recipes end up burnt with inconsistent textures and tasting more like the raw ingredients and less like a finished cookie.  Beth's Spicy Oatmeal Raisin Cookies turned out so well, I decided to see what my young toddler thought of them. Suddenly, after eating these cookies, she no longer throws temper tantrums and has begun to speak several words in Japanese. I couldn't believe it.  These cookies were not only a godsend for me, however, but they also saved someone's life. I gave two dozen of these cookies to a friend over the holidays. Unfortunately, they got buried in the trunk of their car and forgotten about, until the blizzard hit in February. Even after several months in the trunk, when my friends got stranded for 3 days in their car during the blizzard, these cookies were just as warm, soft and fresh as the day they cam out of the oven. Jimmy and Sara owe their lives to those cookies.  If you are down on your luck, need to build confidence or even shed a few pounds, these cookies may do the trick. Their amazing miracle powers should not be underestimated.  Sincerely, Betsy Kilbourne

Good oatmeal cookies, but I still prefer the recipe on the container of Quaker brand oats. This recipe is very similar, the only difference is this recipe uses cloves along with half butter half shortening. I prefer oatmeal raisin cookies made with all butter instead. The addition of the cloves is very nice, but the 1/2 teaspoon was a bit too much for us. Next time I will use all butter, and cut down the cloves to 1/4 teaspoon. Thanks for sharing :)

text:
Absolutely delicious, i didnt have any cloves on hand so I simply ommitted them. A word to the bakers not having success, I found the trick to getting light fluffy cookies with a little crunch is to whip the butter first, then whip the sugar eggs etc into the butter (an electric mixer is perfect for the job. Use the mixer to blend in the flour. gently fold in the oats and raisins. For plump raisins, soak in hot water for 10 minutes prior to adding them, then drain well and add to your cookies. Bake for 8-9minutes (using a tablespoon measurement for sizing) at 350. Delicious!!! Ive never seen cookies disappear so fast!!!!

Display Name:
EmmLee

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3570286.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a very good recipe. As others have noted, it's nearly identical to the Quaker Oats recipe - but that doesn't mean it's not good! My changes were VERY minor: 1) I used margarine instead of the butter/shortening combo (just my preference. I use all butter when I want a crisper cookie) AND 2) I used 1 tsp pumpkin pie spice rather than the cinnamon and cloves. Other things I found helpful to make a perfect batch of these cookies: I whisked the eggs before pouring them into the butter/sugar/vanilla mix, and then blended THAT with a whisk (gently) until smooth. No hand blender. I also folded in the dry ingredients in order using a wooden spoon until just incorported. I soaked my raisins in hot water while prepping the batter (makes for a much better raisin texture/taste). I refrigerated the dough between batches, and let the baked cookies cool on the pan a minute or so to set up before moving them onto a cookie rack to cool. NOTE: This recipe works just as well with fast-cooking oats as it does with regular rolled oats. It's even good with the multi-grain oats. Adding some walnuts and even pumpkin seeds tastes great too - especially when using pumpkin pie spice!

text:
To anyone who is getting cookies that are all crumbly, slightly underbake, then leave the cookies on the cookie sheet for at least 10 minutes after taking them out of the oven. This allows them to finish cooking without getting crispy. Every cookie recipe I've tried does better with this single tip (and I've made a lot of different cookies). 

I followed this recipe exactly, except I used butter instead of crisco and added 1/2 tsp baking powder and they turned out perfectly.

userID:
2364255
Display Name:
faeriecat

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/59547.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love the addition of cloves to this classic oatmeal cookie recipe. It gives them just a little more kick and did indeed make my kitchen smell heavenly on this cold winter day! 

I like to try and "healthy up" treat recipes, so I made some small changes. First I substituted a cup of wheat flour for the white to get some more whole grain in there. Since wheat flour doesn't rise as well as white, I also added a half teaspoon more baking soda. Instead of the shortening I used unsweetened applesauce, which made the dough just a little too wet, so I added another eighth cup or so of wheat flour.
 
As per others' suggestions I soaked the raisins in some boiling water for a few minutes, and that made a big difference. Instead of getting all bitter and shrivelly, the raisins stayed plump and juicy. 

I also recommend flattening the cookie dough a bit when you drop it onto the baking sheet. I love that these cookies don't spread very much.

The finished product: moist, chewy, just barely crisp on the edges, and very very good. These are sure to be gobbled up by my family when they all get home this afternoon!

I used all butter instead of a combination of butter/shortening based on the other reviews. I also added dried cranberries to make them a little different. They bake more evenly and are the perfect combination of soft and chewy. A little over teaspoon sized is what worked best for me (which is the size the recipe suggests). They were delicious and a huge hit at my office party! Great recipe!

text:
Great recipe!!!  Texture is perfect.  They came out with a just little crispness on the outside and super soft and chewy on the inside.  I made a few changes (can't help myself)... I'm not too crazy about cloves so instead I used a couple pinches each of ground clove, nutmeg and allspice.  Also I made a Brown Butter Cinnamon Glaze to drizzle over the top.  It was 1/2 stick butter over medium heat until slightly browned, remove from heat and add 1 and 1/2 cups confectioners sugar, 1/2 teaspoon vanilla, cinnamon to taste (not much, maybe 1/8 to 1/4 tsp.) and about 2 tablespoons water (just enough to get it to drizzle consistency).  Then just drizzle over the cookies and let it harden.  YUM!!!

text:
I modified this recipe quite a bit to make it a bit healthier. They still came out really good! I used 3/4 c. butter instead of the shortening, 1/2 wheat & 1/2 white flour, Splenda in place of sugar (I think I might do half real sugar next time. I like things on the sweeter side), 2 cups of Quaker old fashioned oats & 1 cup of Trader Joe's spiced pumpkin flax seed granola cereal (for added omega 3's & 6's and a tiny bit of crunch).

I like my cookies moist & a little softer so I baked them for only 10 mins and they came out perfect. I think these would be excellent with chocolate chips as well. 

They smell amazing.

These were delicious!  I made a couple changes to make them a little healthier and my family never knew the difference.  Instead of white flour I used soft white wheat and instead of plain oatmeal I used a 7-grain mix that has oatmeal, flaked rye, barley, etc.  This blend is heavier so I reduced the oats to 2 cups.  The cookies were fantastic.  Highly recommend them!

text:
EXCELLENT! I lack the ability to be a great baker, so I don't bake many things, especially oatmeal cookies. They are my husbands favorite, but I don't make them because every time I have tried, they are hard as rocks. This recipe was something that even I can make. They turned out fantastic! The whole family loved them. They are soft, and chewy, and we love the great flavors. I did take some advice from previous reviews, and when my first batch came out a little flat, I added 1/2 teaspoon more of baking soda. I made more 48 hours later when they were all gone. This time I put in 2 teaspoons of baking soda, and love the thickness of the cookies, it's perfect for us. I also kept the dough in the fridge while baking each batch. Couldn't ask for a better tasting cookie! Thanks for the great recipe, that even the baking challenged can cook properly :).

text:
Oh, yum.  I halved this recipe, knowing that it makes quite a deal more than the stated 36 cookies. Used all butter, and reduced the cloves to half. (I'll probably use the suggested amount next time!) I soaked the raisins in hot water to ensure that they'd remain juicy. Because these cookies will be quite flat otherwise, I'd recommend chilling the dough in between batches. At 350 F, my tablespoon sized balls took 10 minutes to be done. ( I like them on the softer side.) Made roughly 3 dozen, even after halving the recipe. This is one of the best cookies out there. So chewy!

text:
I've never been a huge fan of oatmeal raisin cookies. However, my boyfriend loves them so I went on a search for the perfect recipie. My search ends with this one here. 
After a year of baking them, I've only changed a few things. I sift in a small package of vanilla instant pudding mix with the flour and increase the cloves to a 1/2 tsp (we like the spiciness!). I like chunkier cookies so increased the raisins to about 2 cups.
Thank you for sharing such a wonderful recipie!

None
text:
I've finally found an oatmeal raisin cookie recipe I'm thrilled with.  Nice crunch to the exterior with a chewy interior. As with other tinkerers, I made some slight changes.  I put in a splash of buttermilk (probably 1 - 2 Tbs.)and a serving teaspoonful of molasses.  Due to the added moisture, I added another 2 Tbs. flour.  For my family's tastes, I cut the cinnamon to 1/2 teaspoon and little sprinklings of cloves, nutmeg, and ginger for additional interest.  The next time I make these--and there will be one--I will increase the raisins to 1 1/2 cups.  I think any nuts, baking chips, candy, fruit, etc. would be wonderful.

I'm not sure why I feel the need to add a review after over 1500 others have said how wonderful these cookies are, but I don't seem to be able to help myself!  I think it must have something to do with my inability to stop eating them once they are out of the oven...  This has become my husband's favorite "new" cookie! I will never go back to the recipe I have used for the last 30+ years.  I do add an additional 1/2 tsp of cinnamon and 1/2 tsp nutmeg, but that is just personal preference.  Just make them and you and your family will enjoy them.  They are so very delicious.

text:
These were great!! I cut the recipe down to 2 dozen...BIG MISTAKE.  They were sooo good, I might have to make them again soon. I didn't have the butter flavored shortening, so I just used all butter.  And my 5 y/o DD decided they would be good with carmel filled chocolate chips, boy was she right.  Also I didn't have any brown sugar so I used a more natural sugar called Rapadura (2/3 cup) and 1/3 cup white sugar. Also I wasn't sure if I could but I used quick cook oats and they were fine. I can't wait to share this at Bible Study tonight, if there are any left to take.  I can't keep my kids out of them.  Thanks for the recipe!  These are the best oatmeal raisin cookies ever.

text:
This was really good.  I used a medium-sized cookie scoop and came out with 3 dozen cookies exactly.  I didn't have any butter flavored shortening, so I used regular shortening and margarine.  I also ran out of raisins for the last batch, so I used craisins instead.  The ground cloves really add a whole lot to the depth of flavor.  Also, I would not recommend baking these for more than 9 minutes.  They may be super soft coming out of the oven, but they get a lot firmer the next day.  YUMMY!

text:
These are terrific.  Be sure not to overbake them.  I take them out just as the edges start to brown.  They should still be soft in the middle when they cool.  Be sure to soak the raisins in some warm water before mixing into the dough so that they plump up.  

I like the recipe as is, but I sometimes omit the cloves for a more traditional oatmeal raisin cookie.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Well, it is certainly safe to say that I will NEVER use another oatmeal cookie recipe ever again! These cookies were absolutely delicious.  Not only have I never baked such amazing oatmeal cookies, but I don't think I've ever even TASTED such amazing oatmeal cookies!  I made the cookies less than 24 hours ago and they are all gone.  The texture/consistency was perfect - so soft and chewy - and the flavour was amazing (the 'spice' flavour from the cloves and cinammon was perfect).  I made a few minor changes - instead of using butter and butter flavoured shortening, I used all margarine (it was all I had on hand and it certainly didn't negatively affect the cookies), and I added more cinammon.  Also, I probably cooked the cookies for only 8 or so minutes because I hate overdone cookies and I like them to be extra soft.  Also, I scaled down the recipe to 24 servings, and yet I still made 33 medium sized cookies.  Next time I will NOT scale down the recipe because I will want to make more so they will last a bit longer!!  GREAT RECIPE!!!

text:
I have made these, as the recipe stated, with butter-flavored shortening, and I've made them with butter only; and both my husband & I agree, they are much better with butter alone.  I also used pecans, and golden raisins (goldens stay softer and plumper).  I also added 1 tsp cardamom because I just love that spice.  These cookies were SO good!  I was craving oatmeal raisin cookies for weeks, and this did the trick.  It made just over 3 dozen; baked them day before yesterday and there are two left with 3 people in the household.  Guess who ate the most?  Uh-huh!  Me! :(  UPDATE 07/11/06: My mom used to make oatmeal chocolate chip cookies, so I used this recipe today for that, again using butter only, omitting the spices and adding 1c semi-sweet chocolate chips and 1c pecan halves.  SLURP!

text:
Follow the recipe as written. These are great cookies. As directed...do not over bake. Watch carefully and check them starting at about 8 or 9 minutes rather than just set the timer for 10 to 12. They may very well over bake and this five star cookie becomes a 1 star cookie. If over baked the flavor and wonderful chewy texture is lost. Also, soak the raisins first. Makes a world of difference.

text:
Good recipe.  I made it as written, except using all butter instead of the shortening.  I needed to bake them about 13 minutes.  For the people who gave this one star and said the cookies were mushy, there are several things to remember.  1. Let butter soften on the counter to room temperature.  Don't soften in the microwave.  2.Make sure you use rolled oats, not quick oats.
3.  Be sure to leave them on the tray for a little after getting them out of the oven as the directions specify.

text:
I have tried many oatmeal cookie recipes, and this one is the best.  I believe it is the combination of half butter crisco (although it's not healthy, shortening makes the BEST cookies) and half butter or margarine.  The other step that seems to make them better is to add the raisins to the beaten eggs and vanilla and let them soak for about an hour.  Add after creaming the butter and shortening with the two sugars and then the flour mixture.  The raisins are "plump" in the finished cookie.

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow! I have searched and searched for a perfect oatmeal raisin cookie recipe. My husband hates raisins and the only oatmeal cookie he likes are peanut butter no-bakes but he loved these. They didn't last long between him and my 2 & 4-year-olds. I doubled the recipe and instead of just cinnamon and cloves, I used 3tsp. cinnamon, 3/4 tsp. nutmeg, 1/4 tsp. cloves, 1/4 tsp. ginger, 1/4 tsp. allspice as spices. I used 1/2 c. butter and 1/2 c. regular shortening. The lack of butter flavored shortening didn't hurt these at all. I also soaked my raisins in hot water first, this helped the cookie stay moist and chewy as well. I baked my cookies for 12 minutes otherwise they were still pale and doughy; at 12 minutes they were perfect and three days later, when the last one was eaten, it was still soft and chewy. This recipe is a keeper!

text:
This recipe is very close to the "Vanishing Oatmeal Raisin Cookies" recipe off the lid of every canister of Quaker Oats, which I recognized because we have made these cookies almost every weekend in my house for years.  The ingredients are even in the same order.

The exception that makes this recipe stand apart is the addition of cloves.  They really add a wonderful spice, and I would never have thought of doing that.  In addition, I liked the half-n-half shortening/butter combination.  I have always replaced butter with butter-flavor shortening for this recipe because it makes them so gooey and chewy, but I think I do prefer it Beth's way.

Great ideas for tweaking what I have always considered to be the best oatmeal raisin cookie recipe anywhere.

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2007-11-20T16:23:44.273
helpfulCount:
5
userID:
2626130
Display Name:
Smartypantsmapman
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love Oatmeal Raisin cookies and my mother always made the best until I tried these. 
I have made some minor modifications which work really well for me.
1. I use DARK brown sugar since the molasses helps keep the cookies moist.
2. Maybe it's my oven but I cook them a little longer than the original recipe (OR).
3. I have found that the butter flavored shortening works better than all butter. Maybe a food chemist can explain why.
4. I increased the amount of cloves to a full teaspoon. Makes the house smell like Christmas, even in July!
5. Make sure the raisins are separated. If they are fresh, they will clump together.
6. I combine all dry ingredients first by putting them in a used butter tub or similar large container and shaking it hard and fast in order to get everything coated well.
7. then I combine the wet ingredients (including the brown sugar because of the molasses) and mix them until they are totally smooth.
8. I also use a cooking stone. If you don't have one, they are great for baking.

country:
None
text:
By far the best soft oatmeal cookie ever! I've tried a lot of oatmeal cookie recipes over the years looking for one that stays soft, isn't more like cake than cookie, isn't so dry that it stays heaped up in a little ball during baking, yet doesn't flatten out too much causing the edges to be thin and crispy. When I first read the ingredients, I wasn't too sure about adding the cloves since I'm not a real big fan of that spice - it can be strong and overpowering. But I decided to try the recipe as is on the first batch. Beth's oatmeal cookies are perfect. I've received so many compliments. I will definitely make these again. I used a pre-heated baking stone; baked the cookies for 11 minutes; pulled the batch out of the oven and let the cookies sit for two minutes on the stone before removing them to a cooling rack. Using a size 50 mini ice cream scooper yielded 4 dozen cookies.

I used all butter (unsalted) and added an additional 1/2 teaspoon baking powder and a shake more cinnamon. I also soaked the raisins before adding to the cookie dough.  I scooped out the cookies onto a large baking sheet and refrigerated the dough until well chilled.  As each batch was baking, the rest remained in the fridge.  This resulted in a nice thick cookie, just the way my daughter likes them.  This has become her new favorite cookie.  Thanks Beth!

Man, Mrs. Sigworth can sure make some cookies! These are fabulous, I've been looking for a chewy/crispy-edged oatmeal cookie for a while now, and my search is over!  I didn't have butter flavored shortening, but they tasted fine with regular shortening.  I thought the spices were great, but obviously, if you're not a fan of spices you may want to decrease the amt. but I love them as is. I used currants soaked in brandy instead of raisins (since I didn't have any and my b/f loathes raisins) which was pretty good. Altough my b/f made me promise to make them without raisins/currants next time. I'd like to try them with golden raisins and some coconut or nuts...the possibilities are endless. But instead I must try Beth's choc. chip cookies!! (Beth's snickerdoodles are the best cookies I've ever made!!!) Thanks again, Beth!  Add more recipes!!!

userID:
14922300
Display Name:
I used to be a Baker
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
13
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a tale of my night, pieced together from my friends, and the contents of my counter this morning.
Last night, I was a great many things; sober not among them.
I admit, I did some drinking. I had had a very bad day. My fiancé was upset with me, and I was feeling like  when I should have been ecstatic. Not fun.
I had used this recipe before, and I enjoyed the cookies, but I'm not much of a reviewer. Last night, however, was bake night. I used to work in a bakery, and ever since I had to quit (surgery), I have had some friends over once a month for bake night. When my friends arrived, I suddenly realized what night it was. I don't remember much of the night, but this recipe was up, and I clearly used it, so here is what I know:
A glaze drizzle was involved. I know that I used straight cream at first. Must have had to thin it out. I tasted what was left in the fridge and dark rum is the prime suspect.
Chocolate and beer were added. Friend saw me add beer; I can't imagine adding enough to make the cookies as dark as they turned out.
Currants instead of raisins. That's for sure.
There's Irish cream in either the glaze or cookies; apparently I poured myself a glass and I HATE Irish cream, but will never waste booze.
LOTS of spice. They are almost hot from the cinnamon.
Ginger?
On my counter are the following: apricot nectar, pineapple juice, Coke, pear vodka, tequila, rum, and Like a Sir e-juice. Any or all of them may have made it into the cookies. Delicious, though.

text:
Made according to recipe except added an extra half cup of raisins.  Great texture and beautiful appearance.  Just too much cloves for me.  I am softening another half cup of butter on the counter to make another batch and cut the cloves to one quarter teaspoon.  I am a personal chef and my son's teacher wanted me to make him some oatmeal raisin cookies.  I just can't send this first batch to school with my son.  The overpowering cloves made me cough. I believe with that small modification this will make a very delightful oatmeal raisin cookie.  I think the amount of cloves is just a matter of personal preference.  Thank you so much for the recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We thought these were GREAT oatmeal raisin cookies. This is now my official Oatmeal Raisin Cookies. I followed the recipe as written with the exception of using regular shortening instead of butter-flavored shortening and quicks oats instead of regular rolled. (It's what I had on hand.) I always use my Pampered Chef cookie scoop when making cookies. I used the small scoop (1 tbsp) for the first batch which made small cookies; about 2 bites and required a 10 min baking time. Then for the rest I used my medium scoop (2 tbsp) and this made nice BIG cookies. I preferred them. They needed to bake 14 min and I flattened them slightly by pressing on them with my fingers before putting them in the oven to bake.  I ended up with 4 dozen cookies.

None
text:
These cookies are so good I cannot stop eating them!
I read reviews and did some tweaking...I used 1 cup of butter as I did not have the butter flavoured shortening. I omitted the white sugar all together and added 1/4 tsp of nutmeg. I soaked my raisins in boiling water as I prepped everything and this made them plump and soft. 
I used my medium size scoop for the dough and flattened them slightly. I baked them for the full 12 minutes as they were thick and they are amazingly moist!
Honestly this is the best oatmeal raisin cookie I have ever had and I am trying really hard to leave some for the rest of the family!

text:
I FINALLY got around to making these, and yikes, I've already eaten 7 of them! I think the flavor is delicious; I personally love the cloves in this recipe. IMO, they are plenty sweet (and I even reduced the white sugar to 1/4c.). I also used all butter. They did turn out quite thin and flat but when fully cooled are a great chewy texture with a slight crispness to the edges. I used a TBS sized cookie scoop and baked for exactly 11 min.

These cookies are spicy, hence the name. Lots of clove. They came out crispy around the edges and chewy in the center. Used golden raisins. Soaked the raisins in vanilla extract to plump them up. For me, the cookies did take the 10-12 mins to bake however I strongly suggest watching them carefully after 8. The cookies are done when the top is no longer wet and the edges are slightly brown. They quickly go from perfectly baked to overdone.

text:
This is a good basic oatmeal cookie with spices. I had to change it up a bit. First I can't have that much clove so I cut it in half.  I love the taste of cinnamon and vanilla so I doubled those amounts.  Make sure you fold in the oatmeal as it simply isn't as good if you beat it with a blender. It crumbles up the oats until they are fine and it is not a good consistency.  I added chopped walnuts to mine. About 1 cup and they came out delicious though I often make them without nuts.

Display Name:
Food Dreams

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So I decided to change things up a bit for Christmas. Beth's Spicy Oatmeal Raisin cookies. I was thinking about pine trees and egg nog and then I started thinking about cinnamon, which somehow made me start thinking about oatmeal although I don't see any connection on that last part..  The whole process was fairly straight forward. We didn't use shortening, and substituted with only butter. We also decided to make 2 flavors!:   1) Oatmeal Raisin  2) White Chocolate Walnut Oatmeal Raisin  These cookies really spread out when you start baking so make sure you give them room or they will combine with the adjacent cookie and result in a complex phenomena called "cookie-neighboring".    The cookies were slightly soft after baking, but the following day they were crispy at the edges and chewy in the center. I firmly believe the taste had improved after waiting a day. We liked both flavors but agreed the traditional Oatmeal Raisin flavor was better, and went fantastic with a Starbucks Latte.   Next time, I would use slightly less sugar, maybe a 1/4 cup of granulated sugar than 1/2 cup. And I would add more raisins! I hear if  you soak the raisins in boiling water they will become more plump and moist! I'll have to implement that as well. All in all, a great recipe and appropriate for the holidays. BAKE OR DIE!

city:

region:

country:

text:
These were absolutely incredible.  I didn't have any cloves on hand, so I omitted them.  I added a little extra cinnamon, as well as a dash of both ginger and nutmeg.  I used all butter. I boiled my raisins until they were plump prior to adding them to the mix.  I forgot to dust them in flour to dry them a little, and therefore my cookies wouldn't stay together due to being too moist (No one seemed to mind, as they disappeared before my eyes!). I also used the cinnamon "glaze" (more like an icing, really) which totally topped it off.  Note:  They will NOT look done after 9-10 minutes. They'll be puffy and still light.  Take them out, they will flatten and look like oatmeal raisin cookies once they're cool. :o)  My boyfriend and I are making them again this weekend!

text:
I know that this recipe doesn't need any more reviews, but I just wanted to say that, like others, this is the best oatmeal cookie I think I've ever eaten. I found the cinnamon and cloves very pleasing and not overpowering at all like some thought. I followed the recipe to the letter and wouldn't change a thing. I doubled the recipe so that I could give cookies for gifts this Christmas (but you'd better have a very large bowl!). I'll be honest with you, I thought that the original recipe for 36 cookies would be for little tiny cookies but to my surprise, I made them about 3 inches in diameter and there was plenty of cookie dough for 36 cookies. Now I have oatmeal cookies coming out of my ears! I'll freeze some, give some as gifts and of course EAT lots. They are good for breakfast - like a quick bowl of oatmeal cereal right in a cookie! THANK YOU for sharing this recipe!

text:
Okay, at 35 yrs old I am JUST learning to cook beyond the microwave, so mistakes are likely.  FIRST LESSON: I forgot the flour (how does THAT happen!?!) and found a sticky oozing mess when I checked the first batch.  SECOND LESSON: the recipe does not specify (for us beginners) to use salted or unsalted butter. I used salted and the additional salt. My suggestion to others like me who do not know better is to use one or the other, not both. THIRD LESSON: This recipe is a little sweet for me (it tastes "store bought" sweet) so I may try to cut back the sugar next time.  FOURTH LESSON: Cutting back the baking time to about 10 minutes saved me from hard cookies, but now I find them chewy.  ADDITIONS: 1/4 tsp Cardamom for depth to the spicy flavor.  YUMMY even if a tad salty and chewy!

(6)Yes. These are a good cookie. If you omitted the cloves and used butter, you'd have a clone of another well-known cookie. TIP: When I made oatmeal raisin cookies, I will sometimes use a dried mixed berry blend or dried cranberries in place of the raisins. For plumper raisins, soak them in hot water/juice for about 45 minutes and drain well before adding them to your cookie dough.

city:

text:
This is a review for my "healthy" version of these cookies. I took some pointers from other posts and then changed a few things on top of that to make these healthy. I'm sure this version pales in comparison to the original but since I have not tried the original I was happy with the results. Here are my changes: Substitute applesauce for butter and shortening, only used half of the amounts of the brown and white sugars, 1/2 c. egg beaters instead of eggs, whole wheat flour instead of white, additional 1/2 tsp. baking soda, additional 1 tsp. cinnamon, 1/2 tsp. nutmeg and 1/2 tsp. allspice, omitted cloves, added a package of sugar free vanilla pudding, brought water to a boil and added a splash of vanilla and then added the raisins and covered so they were nice and juicy and finally I sprayed my cookie sheets with cooking spray to prevent sticking. I baked them for 9 minutes and was very happy with the results.  I calculated these to be 1 Weight Watchers point each!

I used all butter instead of 1/2 cup of butter flavored shortening.  If you go with this modification be prepared to add a little more flour (add 1/8 to 1/4 c).  Before I added the additional flour the cookies flattened out a little more than what I wanted.  The flavor is excellent and they were gone quickly.  This recipe is absolutely a keeper!

text:
These were WONDERFUL cookies! I didn't have all of the items on hand (it happens when you're broke!) so I substituted a few items. I will list them just in case anyone else is in my boat :)   I did not add vanilla since I did not have any, I also doubled the cinnamon and per posters I added 1/4 tsp ginger and 1/2 tsp of nutmeg.  I also did not use cloves since I did not have any. I used a whole cup of butter and omitted the shortening, and finally, I did not have "rolled oats" so I just used packed instant oatmeal. It took about 6 packets of Cinnamon & Spice instant oatmeal to equal 3 cups. I was a little uneasy about it but they turned out wonderful! I was able to roll the dough around in my hand to make little balls and I cooked it like that. BEAUTIFUL!

text:
LOVED THESE!!! I think that the cloves really made the difference in this recipe...made the house smell great and added a good flavor to the cookies. This recipe works well with craisins (dried cranberries) too. Perfect mix of chewy and crispy. One word of warning, though...make sure not to overcook the cookies. They don't look like they are done after 11 minutes, but if you cook them longer, they get overcooked. Just wait the two minutes before taking them off of the cookie sheet and they will be fine!

These are fabulous!! I made a batch of 18 - which came out to about 25. With a few alterations these turned out fantastic. I upped the cinnamon, added allspice, nutmeg, and a little bit of vanilla pudding dry mix (to keep moist. These are SUPER tasty.  I completely omitted the white sugar and only used the 1 cup of brown and they were still VERY sweet.  I also used only whole wheat flour in place of the white flour.  This is a much healthier alternative and the raisins still make them sweet and tasty!  I bake at 350 for only 8 minutes and they were PERFECT!  This recipe makes a TON of cookies so you might want to cut the recipe in half if you have a small family.

phenomenal!
i changed this bit: instead of butter + shortening, i used 1 cup smart balance. "top off" (add a little more) light brown sugar, and a little less white sugar. and i cheat on the cinnamon too, adding a little more. 4 cups oats (i just eyeball it to see if it should need more. definitely more than 3 cups). 2 cups raisins (eyeball, more than 1 cup).

text:
This is the same recipe that I get from the underside of the lid of the Quaker Old Fashioned Oat Meal and have been using for years and years. I use ALL Crisco and add about 1/2 tsp. extra of cinnamon. I bake for only 9 mins. and let the heat finish baking them once they are out of the oven. This way they are big and puffy and soft but do not fall apart. The best cookies ever!

un-remarkable.  I made 72 cookies (doubled recipe) to take to a company cookie exchange.  I did not get any compliments.  The dough tasted great raw but the cookie was lacking.  I would double the cinnamon and cloves next time if I made again.  I also had trouble getting the baking time right.  10 minutes seemed under-done and they were too gooey (not just soft) they were raw in the middle but if I let them cook longer they got too done.  They were edible but not delicious like I was hoping they would be.  Sorry :(

text:
Well, I love oatmeal cookies, but it is esp nice when you find one that EVERYONE likes, even the non-oatmeal fans. The spices are standard, but the balance is nice in this one. I used the golden raisins, as I think they taste better and look better in a cookie.  I have made these a few times now, and also tried it with chopped walnuts.  Every batch has been a hit, easy to make and so tasty! But, I'll always stand by the golden raisins as the best! (Soak them in boiling water first, then toss them in a little bit of flour. That way, the raisins are juicy, not dried out hard bits.)  Yummy overall!  Thanks!

text:
I hate to give this recipe a bad rating but the truth is that I really dont care for the cookies.  They have a great appearance but the flavor is lacking.  I do want to add that I wasnt able to use packed brown sugar and I soaked the raisins in rum.  If I had it to do again, I would not soak the raisins, I would be sure to use the correct sugar and I would leave out the clove.  It seems like it would add to the flavor of a great cookie but ultimately that is the only taste left in your mouth.  Nevertheless, the cookies are simple to prepare so give it a try and dont let my review discourage you!

country:

text:
Help!  I made these last night and now I can't stop eating them!  Gave away 1 1/2 dozen which still leave me with way too many.....lol   I've been wanting to try this recipe for a long time and finally got to it.  It will be in my fav. recipe book soon.  Even my mailcarrier asked for a copy of the recipe today when I gave him some.  I did make minor changes (added a bit of nutmeg and allspice, plus increased the amt of cinnamon; used chopped dates instead of raisins, and added toasted pecans) but the basic cookie dough was perfect. Nice, big chewy cookies!   Tips: 1)Softened butter is not the same as melted butter--you need to know the difference.  2) If I want chewy cookies I try to watch them closely and remove them from the oven when they appear to be slightly 'puffy' in the middles.  The heat of the oven makes the moist ingredients so hot they expand somewhat and if you take them out at that point they will remain moist and chewy.  If the 'puffiness' is gone it will be a
crispier cookie.  Hope this helps.  Beth, now I can't wait to test your other listings--thanks so much for sharing! (even though it is going to kill my diet....)

An excellent, excellent cookie recipe! Like other reviewers I also used an extra 1/2 cup of butter instead of shortening. I substituted the cinnamon with pumpkin pie spice, and added 3/4 cup of walnuts. They taste even better if you leave them in a sealed container overnight to let the flavors blend, the next day they are much softer and taste even better! I will definitely make these over and over again, I’m also planning on making a batch to send to my husband who is deployed overseas right now. Thanks so much for this great recipe!

I made a cookie platter for work today: chocolate chip, peanut butter, and these.  In past experience, the other two flavors are always the first to go.  I decided to try these, just to add some variety, and they were by far the most complimented.   Men were tracking me down to say things like, "I've eaten a lot of cookies, and these were the best I've ever had".   If I keep making things like this, I will be a popular girl in the office, that's for sure!   Thank you so much for sharing this one - it's a keeper!  The only thing I changed was to use all Butter Flavored Crisco...it's my secret ingredient in a lot of baked goods.  It keeps the cookies soft and they don't fall flat when cooled.

text:
I thought this was a good basic oatmeal cookie. It kind of reminded me of the recipe on the oatmeal box I have tried before. The only change I made was using all butter. My main issue, was there was just a little too many raisins for my taste. I was trying to make about 2 dozen for a party cookie platter. I made a 1/2 recipe and got 27 cookies using a cookie scoop. They will work great for the party, and I believe they will be well received.

THIS IS BETH'S RECIPE AND IT IS THE BEST!!!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been cooking since I was 4, but only just started baking.  I love oatmeal cookies and this is the first cookie recipe I tried and I'll never make another.  It's the best oatmeal raisin cookie I've ever had.  I followed the advice of others using only butter, baking less (9 min)  and adding ginger (luv ginger too, lol) and added in some craisins too.  I found the extra plump raisins in these cookies are amazing.  You can find them at BJ's. I also baked it on parchment paper.  No chance of sticking to the cookie sheet and extremely easy clean up, just throw away the paper.  I made them for Thanksgiving and everyone went crazy for them.  They're a great match with home made cinnamon ice cream,  We started making ice cream sandwiches out of them.  Not only did they disappear quickly, have to double or triple the recipe next time but they were fun, the ic sandwiches, lol.

text:
These were great!  To make mixing a little easier though, you can mix the first wet ingredients with the mixer and after adding the dry ingredients, use the mixer again!  Just stir in the raisins.  In our house, and oatmeal cookie has to have coconut though, so I used some coconut flavouring and 3/4 cup shredded coconut as well.  I also like my cookies to look uniform in size, so I roll into 2" or 3" balls and then flatten with a fork.  Thanks for sharing!

Susan

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! I made these with all butter and 1/2 tablespoon of cinnamon, just cause I like cinnamon. Don't leave out the ground cloves, they really add to the flavor. Try soaking the raisins in about 1/3 cup of Triplesec and enough water to cover the raisins then microwave till the liquid and raisins are to the boiling point...let them soak and cool for 10 minutes or so then drain off the remaining liquid ( there won't be much left) and add the raisins...make sure the raisins have cooled off though! This step plumps the raisins and adds a subtle hint of flavor to them which of course, makes these cookies even better!  Thanks for the recipe!

Okay they had a great flavor but I really had to tweak the cooking times and temperature of my convection oven and I still haven't come up with the perfect time/temp. Also these cookies were a little too thin and crispy. I think I'll increase the flour and decrease the oatmeal nxt time. I also think making them with  walnuts will be really good! UPDATE: I let them sit overnight and now they r sssooo soft and chewy and not crispy at all! Definitely five stars now!

text:
This recipe is delicious! I do all butter, about double the cinnamon. I also do it with cranberries, (I use the dried, sweetened ones) and depending on the ones you get, you might want to add a little more sugar. I soak the raisins or cranberries for 10 minutes in warm water before putting them in the mixture. As a fundraiser for my church we sell baked goods and I make these every week and people love them! If you like cranberries, they are amazing with them! I haven't tried blueberries or any other berry in them, but I'm sure that would be delicious too! Thank you for this recipe!!

text:
Modified to make these HEALTHY FIRST:  instead of 1/2 cup shortening substitued 1/2 cup apple regular sauce SECOND: instead of 1 1/2 cup all purpose flour substituted 1 cup whole wheat and 1/2 cup all purpose THIRD: instead of 1/2 cup white sugar substituted 1/2 cup more rasins  Everything else was exactly the same.  Cookies came out great - not crunchy but softer.  Plenty sweet.  Always make sure butter is somewhat firm.  These didn't spread, when you put a dolop of dough on the cookie sheet you have to flatten it a bit.  Loved the spicyness.

text:
these were excellent! nice and moist as well as yummy. however, a trick to having nice and plump cookies rather than flat ones is to keep the batter chilled in between the batches going in and out of the oven. that way the butter melts in the oven when baking rather than while the batter is sitting out waiting to be baked.

text:
It's hard for me to say this......but these cookies beat the socks off my mother's famous oatmeal cookies.  The cloves add this very interesting element that makes you want more.  While I might use a little less (1/4 tsp) if making it for a crowd where they might be picky eaters, for me the cloves were perfect.  I also added 1/8 tsp allspice, nutmeg and ginger to the dry ingredients for a bit more complexity.  I also soaked the raisins to plump them up a bit (my mom's famous recipe does this, so I figured it's a always a good idea).  I bragged about these to her so much, she's having make these for X-Mas this year instead of her recipe.  I'm nervous, but I don't think this one will let anybody down.  It's awesome!

The cookies were a disappointment. I chose this recipe because of the high reviews it had but should have went with another. The cookies were not sweet enough, were on the crumbly side and the cloves ruined the taste. I did find that the longer the cookie sat the better it tasted but I don't know that any amount of time can save these cookies. My advice, if you're gonna make these leave out the cloves and let them sit for a day.

text:
I made these cookies tonight and they were a big hit. Very tasty, not too sweet - love the clove kick. I did take the advice of others and soaked the raisins for 10 minutes in hot water then drained and patted them dry with paper towels before adding them to the mix. It is a great tip that prevents you from having hard raisin flavored tar chewys in your cookies. Also, all I had on hand was extra thick organic rolled oats because they are extra thick I only used 2 1/2 cups of oats. The flavor, consistancy, and the aroma made for an awesome cookie expreience. Thanks for the recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a nice oatmeal recipe but like everyone else there is a distinct taste that you are going for that you remember from growing up.   I tweaked this recipe and found the perfect combo of spicy, sweet and crunch.  I used a whole cup of butter and skipped the shortening.   I increased my sugar to a cup. Added in 1/2 teaspoon of ginger and 1/2 teaspoon of nutmeg. I replaced 1/2 the regular flour w/whole wheat flour and added a 1/2 cup of finely chopped toasted walnuts.  I omitted the cloves because I've never had it in my oatmeal cookies before and it just didn't sound appealing.  The end result is so perfect that my guy literally closed his eye while he was eating and said they were incredible.   I like a lil bit of a crunch around the edge so I cooked it a minute longer.   The wheat flour adds a darker color to the cookie  so you have to carefully watch and not depend on the color to tell if it is done.  Please let me know if you enjoy.

text:
So this recipe has been in my recipe box for quite some time.  Every time that I go to make it, I find something else to make or go back to my usual oatmeal cookie recipe.  Tonight, I decided that for sure this is what I was going to make.  I debated whether to try and make this recipe healthier like I usually try to do and decided to give it a go and if it didn't work then I wouldn't rate it until I tried it again as written.  So I added 1/2 cup butter and 1/2 cup applesauce.  I also don't really care for cloves, so I used nutmeg as some other reviewers did.  Everything else stayed the same.  I am a cookie dough lover and so, of course, I had to try the dough. At this point in the recipe, all was great.  Scooped them onto the cookie sheet, flattened a little and baked for 10 minutes.  Cooled for a few minutes on the sheet and removed.  They are WONDERFUL!!!  Even without the full 1 cup of butter, so I am sure that they are even better than what I am tasting.  This is replacing my usual recipe and I will definitely be making these often.

text:
I'm a retired male and this is the first recipe I ever made, because I'm a lover of oatmeal raisin cookies.  I made it the first time with 2 sticks of butter because I didn't have butter flavored shortening on hand.  They came out good, but a little crispy for me, but others thought they were great.  The next time I used the butter flavored shortening and I thought they came out too pasty.  The third time I went back to the 2 sticks of butter and made larger cookies and cooked for 10 min.  They came out just right and they were gone in no time flat.  I've made several times since and they always come out great.  Now I'm on to peanut butter cookies, my second favorite.  Wish me luck.

None
text:
Awesome cookies! I make about 100 dozen cookies every Xmas and I am always in search of great tasting cookie recipes. This is a keeper! I used all butter as several did. I increased the white sugar to almost a cup and I added walnuts because we love nuts. Here's my tip......process 2 cups of the oatmeal to a fine powder and leave the remaining cup as is. This will give your cookies that "nutty" consistency you are looking for. No food processer? No problem...I used one of those little mini ultimate chopper things or just use your blender. Also always use parchment paper to line your cookie sheet pan and don't over bake. These cookies are wonderful! Enjoy!

these cookies are a fave in my household & only seem to get better with each day!  i highly recommend simmering the raisins in hot water for about 4 minutes before mixing them into the batter.. Remember to drain them well!  Doing this helps keep the raisins soft as the cookies bake and helps keep the cookie fresh & softer longer!! yummmmmmm even tom the turkey wants one from the oven beloooowwwww! a thanksgiving hit for sure!

None
text:
Excellent recipe, I'm not fond of cloves and will probably use allspice next time but I always make the first recipe exactly as stated, how else can you rate it, if you change it?  Just a side note to those that are having difficulties: Humidity affects cookies, as does high altitude.  If you are in a humid place or just having a humid day, use a little bit less "liquid".  If you are in high altitude, use less butter/shortening and a little bit more flour.  These are standard cooking changes for dealing with climate.  Hope this helps.

userID:
1479069
Display Name:
Aimathena
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2

5

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/964383.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did alter it a bit, due to what I had on hand. e.g. 2 c's oats + 1 c of granola cereal. 1 1/2 sticks of butter + 1/4 c of regular crisco shortening. I used Craisins because it's what I had in the pantry. I added 1/2 tsp walnut extract. I lined my cookie sheets with wax paper. I used a scoop type tablespoon to measure out the dough, which I rounded over the top of the spoon (I would guestimate it at approx. 1 1/2 tablespoons) It made 40 palm sized cookies. I used long cookie sheets, which I was able to fit 15 cookies on each sheet. I baked both of sheets at the same time, I had to switch them around because the bottom rack of cookies wasn't cooking as fast as the top rack. I had to cook them for 15 minutes, but this was due to having 2 big sheets of cookies in the oven. The 3rd sheet cooked at 10 minutes. Final product produced an ever so slightly cripsy outer edge and a soft and chewy center. PS This is not the same recipe as Quaker's (who cares where it came from, as long as you have it). The amounts of butter and sugars aren't the same, + it doesn't call for cloves. Speaking of the cloves in this recipe... it doesn't make it spicy, it just makes them taste perfect! I have acid reflux & almost everything burns my throat but these cookies didn't. Drizzle icing across the tops by mixing 1 cup confectioners' sugar, 2 1/2 tsp milk, 2 1/2 tsp light corn syrup, 1/2 tsp walnut extract. Very Good Recipe, Thanks Beth!

text:
I adjusted the recipe to make it vegan. I used 1/2 cup Earth Balance margarine (vegetable oil works too), 1/2 cup applesauce to replace the butter and shortening. I used 2 tbs ground flaxseed with 6 tbs water to replace the eggs. I also upped the ground cinnamon to 2 tsp, and added 1 tsp ground nutmeg, and 2 tsp ground allspice. Baked it for 9 minutes. It was delicious. I'm sure the original recipe would be very good too but I didn't have eggs on hand when I made it.

text:
Wow!! These are my absolute favorite cookies from now on. I didn't have all the right ingredients so I just hoped for the best with what I had on hand.
I used 1/2 C regular vegetable shortening and 1 stick of Blue Bonnet light. I cut the sugar way down and used 1/4 C spenda/sugar mix and 1/4 C brown sugar...but I increased vanilla to 2 t. I used Sunmaid raisins and cooked the cookies for 9 min. They were perfect!!! And with the lower sugar amounts I feel a little less quilty after I ate 8 of them (my batch made about 55 cookies). Yum!

text:
these are EXCELLENT! a little chewy and gooey, too. i always use 1 c. whole wheat flour and 1/2 c. a.p. white flour to add some fiber and nutrition. i honestly think it enhances the recipe for the better. i also throw in about 1/4 c. or so of milled flax seed. you can't taste it, but it adds a great heart healthy component to these. i add it to pancakes, biscuits...its undetectable and so good for you. sometimes i'll add a 1/4 c. or so of chopped pecans, too. 
great recipe!

text:
The cookies had good texture, but they were not as sweet as I like my cookies, and were kind of bland.  This may be because I omitted the cloves - I don't like the flavor of cloves and was just trying to find a god basic oatmeal cookie recipe.  I think I'll keep looking.  As a side note, I used all whole-wheat flour because my mom had used all of the all-purpose making buns and the cookies turned out structurally sound.  I usually have problems with dough/batter consistency when using whole wheat but these were great, that way.  Second time through: Used margarine 'cause that's what we had.  First pan was flat, so added about a tbsp more flour and an extra 1/4c of oats and that fixed the problem.  Added 1/2tsp extra cinnamon and  1/2tsp nutmeg.  Again omitted the cloves (I just don't care for cloves!)

text:
UPDATE: I made these cookies again, but instead of using rolled oats and such, I substituted breakfast cereal, some dried cranberries, extra raisins and chocolate chips. Any left over dry cereal would do the trick. 

Dangerous, dangerous cookies to have in your house! These are OMG DELICIOUS!!! So, if you eat all 36 don't say you weren't warned. I used all butter and a mix of raisins and dried cranberries because that's all I had. I didn't have cloves so I substituted the cinnamon and cloves in the recipe for 1 and 1/2 tsp of Chinese Five Spice which contains fennel, anise, ginger, licorice root, cinnamon and cloves. The smell is devine. The smell of the cookies in the oven is heaven and each one I eat, I cannot believe how good these taste. I still give these 5 stars even though I subbed in some more spices and used all butter. I will post some photos of these diet busters!

text:
These are my favorite Oatmeal Raisin Cookies, they definitely have some spice, not a bland oatmeal cookie. I did not change anything about this recipe. Definitely use butter flavored shortening and not plain shortening. If you do not have butter flavored shortening, then just use another stick (1/2) cup of butter. I dropped my cookies onto the sheet as rounded tablespoons not teaspoons and cooked them for 15-16 minutes with the same results!

text:
These turned out wonderful!  After reading about those that found it too soft and breaking apart it seemed that it only happened to those that used all butter rather than 1/2 butter 1/2 shortening.  So I keep with the 1/2 c butter and 1/2 cup butter flavored shortening.  I didn't have clove seasoning, so I used nutmeg.  Do to some of the comments about lack of flavor, I did up the cinnamon to 2 tsp and a full tsp of nutmeg (in replace of the cloves).  Also, I only baked them for 8 minutes (9 minutes for the larger size.)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First, I did make a couple of changes to this recipe. I didn't have ground clove, so I doubled the cinnamon instead. Also, I had no real butter in the house so I used all butter-flavored Crisco instead. Also, I'm a huge nut fan, especially when it comes to oatmeal cookies... so I only added 1/2 cup of raisins (rather than 1 cup) and 1/2 cup of pecans. My problem with this recipe wasn't the flavor but the consistency. It was a very dry batter that needed to be pressed into balls in order to stay together and the cookies never flattened out during baking either, which meant either flattening them or adding an extra 5 minutes to the bake-time.
The flavor was at least a 4 1/2 stars but it wasn't so great that I felt it was worth the extra trouble of trying to keep them together on the sheet or the extra bake time, sorry.

I don't use the butter flavored shortening becaue I just don't like the artificial butter flavor.  I always soak my raisins in very hot water for about 10 minutes and then drain.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make the dough for this and Beth's other cookie recipes and freeze it to give as Christmas gifts. I use a cookie scoop and drop on a baking sheet and freeze 1-2 hours. Then put frozen dough in freezer zip bags. You can bake any flavor, mix and match right out of the freezer. Just place on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper, bake for 13 minutes at 375 degrees. I found you really need to sift the flour then measure. Especially when making multiple batches. I was asked at Thanksgiving by several family members "your still making cookie dough for Christmas right!?!?!" Thanks Beth

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies were delicious, with a few minor changes: I halved the recipe, and upped the oats to 2 cups and the raisins [I used golden] to 1 cup. I wasn't able to use cloves since I didn't have any, but I upped the cinnamon to 1 teaspoon and added 1/4 teaspoon of nutmeg. The first batch [cooked for 9 minutes] was browned more on top that I prefer, so I lowered the temperature to 350 for the second batch and baked them for 10 minutes. They were perfect! With heaping teaspoonfuls of dough, this recipe made a generous 2 dozen, with a bit of dough left over to munch on.

text:
I was lookig for an oatmeal raisin cookie, and this one looked like a winner.it is very similar to quaker's oatmeal raisin cookie recipe, with the addition of cloves. I didn't use the cloves and I added a tad more baking soda, but i like puffy cookies. I also chilled the dough before baking it. I accidently greased my first batch, so they were very flat. the second batch was ungreased and they came out perfectly! They smell heavenly. I also sprinkle cinnamon sugar o them right out of the oven.

I would highly recommend trying other mix-ins!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is by far the best recipe I have yet to make. I didn't have butter flavor shortening, so I just used real butter. Not Margarine.  I did soak my raisins in very warm water while I was preparing the cookies. Also, I baked my cookies for 8 minutes. What I do is roll the cookie dough in a ball, then moisten a bottom of a glass with water and press the ball flat. Be sure to moisten the bottom of the glass after 2 cookies, or they will stick to the glass. My family loved the cookies.

text:
These are very good oatmeal raisin cookies with a wonderful spice flavor. I followed another reviewer's advice and added an additional 1/2 tsp cinnamon, 1/4 tsp ginger and 1/2 tsp nutmeg. That turned out well. However, I followed another reviewer's advice to pull the cookies at 10 minutes, and that left me with 12 underdone cookies that fell apart when I tried to remove them. My slower GE electric oven obviously needs 10-12 minutes. 12 especially for the first batch. Be warned. Otherwise, great cookies.

None
text:
Really enjoyed these. The key to making any cookie stay chewy/soft is to take them out before they're totally done. You have to remove them when they still look just a little wet on top. Leave them for five or ten minutes on the cookie sheet and they will continue to cook and firm up. The shortening/butter in these helps to keep them soft. I added a cup of dried cranberries and a cup of semi sweet chocolate chips and maybe a tablespoon or so more of shortening. Also, I hate when cookies taste too plain and this cookie has lots of flavor thanks to the spices. Great recipe! It will be my new oatmeal cookie recipe.

text:
I had never made oatmeal raisin cookies before these. For some reason I was nervous to deviate from my reliable chocolate chip cookies but I sure am glad I did! These were SO tasty! I loved the cloves in it, it really took the flavor to the next level. 

I wish I would have read the other reviews about using all butter instead of half butter and half butter flavored shortening. Regardless, they turned out great. 

One change I made was that I cut the flour down to 1-1/4 and I added 1 package of instant vanilla pudding. The cookies are so soft and yummy! I definitely reccomend adding the pudding, it really bumps the texture up a notch.

text:
Hi, although I think this is a 5 star recipe on it's own (without a doubt) I DID change a couple of things...  I used all butter, 1 1/4 cup brown sugar & 1/4 cup of white sugar.  The only thing I would change next time I bake these (and there WILL be a next time) I will add more cinnamon.  I found that the last couple of batches I cooked had more body to them.  The next time, I will let the dough set on the counter for 30 to 45 minutes before baking. I made these about golf ball size on the cookie sheet & cooked them for about 17 to 19 minutes. I let them set on the cookie sheet for about 3 minutes before removing them.  Using parchment paper makes removal so easy! I made 28 cookies at this size.  This is THE BEST oatmeal raisin cookie recipe!  They came out with just a little bit of crustiness on top and soft & chewy inside - yummmmm! I compared it to the one on the Quaker oatmeal container & the ingredients are mostly the same but the measurements/amounts are different.  That changes te end result! Plus the addition of the cloves is a great touch.  Don't hesitate to make these cookies!

text:
These cookies are good, but I wouldn't call them spicy.  Next time I'll double the cloves.  I used 1/2 cup butter and 1/2 cup margarine (no trans fats kind) and dark brown sugar rather than light.  Cookies just seem to come out chewier with dark brown sugar.  I used both baking powder and baking soda (1 tsp each) just because I always put both in my cookies.  I also added a little nutmeg (not quite 1/2 tsp.  They do leave a very pleasant after taste in your mouth though.  I only had to bake mine for 7 min. and removed them from the cookie sheets immediately.  Overall, a good cookie, but could be even better with more alterations.

city:

text:
Really liked these alot- husband likes them also. I soaked raisins in boiling water + 1/2 tsp. orange extract to cover for a few minutes. I also thought the cloves would overtake the other flavors so I reduced amount to 1/4 tsp and added 1/8 tsp nutmeg. I used the 1/2 c. butter flavored shortening as called for (I always make cookies using 1/2 shortening-- really improves the texture of the cookie and cuts down on saturated fat). Oh- and added about 1/2 cup chopped walnuts. The result was a light, slightly crispy on edges cookie with subtle spice flavors that complimented the oat/raisin combo without overpowering. Thanks for this tasty recipe.

text:
These are officially my favorite cookies! LOVE this recipe! I never have shortening in the house, so I just use all butter. Bake them on parchment paper for 9 - 10 minutes. They look undone in the middle when I take them out of the oven, but they always end up perfectly crispy on the edges and chewy in the middle. I use Craisins instead of raisins, and also add chocolate chips, white chocolate chips, walnuts, and chopped candied ginger pieces. Ultimate YUMness!!! Thanks, Beth!

text:
This was a good recipe just needed some tweaking and not sure what I need to do different next time.  The first batch at 10 minutes were tood hard and the section batch at 10 minutes were too soft and were falling apart.  They have a really good taste and using the buttered flavored Crisco makes a big difference in how fluffy your cookies will come out.  Using just margarine leaves you with flat cookies.  Great taste just need to work on better consistency, maybe less oats, 2 /12 cups instead of 3.

text:
The first batch I made per the recipe.  Big hit.  I wanted to make some more healthy versions of same.  So I replaced the butter and shortening with smart balance.  The brown sugar with 2/3 cup of Agava nectar and 1 table spoon of molasses.
The sugar was replaced by stevia. 
I used whole wheat all purpose on the later batches also.  One not old style rolled oats not quick oats. 
I also had a batch I made with cranrasins.  All were hits too. I had to mash them down to get the chewy flat look  on all versions. 

Great cookie I made a ton for Christmas gifts.  They freeze well too.

Made some minor changes to boost the fiber content.  Used 1 cup all-purpose flour and 1/2 cup whole wheat.  Used 2 3/4 cups oats and 1/4 cup oat bran.  Finally, added about 2 tablespoons of flaxseed meal.  Also used margarine as I had neither butter nor shortening on hand.  Otherwise, made as directed and they came out dense, hearty, and delicious.  These are a snack cookie that will stave off hunger!

text:
These tasted delicious!  I followed the recipe for the most part.  I did substitute allspice for the cloves.  The first batch I made small tablespoon size balls and baked for 9 minutes at 350degrees.  They were nowhere near done so I let the go for aonther 2 minutes.  They came out flat and see-through!  The next batch I made very large tablespoon size balls and baked for 11 minutes at 375 degrees.  For some reason this kept them from flattening out so much.  Both batches tasted great but the second batch looked a lot more like a cookie rather than a paper doily!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I do not like my cookie hard as a rock. If you are like me and want them soft and chewy, stick to a cooking time of 8 minutes or so. Even the next day, my cookies are still soft and chewy

I like spice. The more the better, so I added 1/4 Teaspoon of Ginger. Instead of ½ cup of butter flavored shortening, I used all butter. So instead of only ½ cup of butter, I increased that to 1 cup. 

The best Oatmeal Cookies I have ever had!
-----------
Update - I still love this recipe. I have a variation to offer. Instead of raisins, I used chocolate chips. For me, the combo of the spice and chocolate worked perfectly. 

Still recommend sticking to all butter unless you just happen to like shortening. Also still recommend a lot of extra spice. That is if you live spice like me. I suggest sticking to the original recipe, except for the shortening, and then branching out from there as your tastes dictates.

text:
I used all butter, skipped the half cup of white sugar and used pumpkin pie seasoning in an equal amount to the spices listed. I also chose to soak my raisins in coffee liqueur (Tia Maria) while I prepared the recipe. After I strained out the raisins and was adding them in I felt the dough seemed dry so I poured in the liqueur as well (about half a cup). I rolled the cookies into balls and baked them as such without flattening. They're the perfect bite, while being crunchy yet chewy.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I would have to add my 5 star rating, if it ever gets read! With every other oatmeal cookie recipe I have tried the cookies spread out so much on my stoneware baking pans. Not, these, they really keep a nice shape. They also use less sugar than other recipes, which lets you enjoy the flavour rather than just the sweet.  I like to make these with Earth Balance "vegan buttery sticks" as I often bake for someone with a dairy allergy, and I use 100% whole wheat flour instead of the white. I do add a teeny bit more baking soda but not sure if this is necessary. Also, I find they take 12-13 minutes on my stoneware pans. And it makes about 5 dozen cookies with my 1 tablespoon dough scoop thingy.  YUM YUM!!

Edit:I usually only use 1/4 cup of super packed brown sugar. An I use chocolate chips!

text:
These are truly an exceptional cookie.  I did make some changes but I think they only enhanced the great recipe that Beth has shared with us.  I used all butter instead of shortening, added a little ground allspice, used Sunmaid Mixed Raisins (Thompson, Golden, and Red Flame, YUM!) For my oatmeal, I used Arrowhead Mills Oat Flakes which is a very sturdy oatmeal and my nuts were sliced almonds.  Together the almonds and the oat flakes added a nice crisp crunch around the chewiness of this fabulous cookie.  Thanx so much for sharing this, Beth!  This will be the standard for oatmeal cookies around here from now on. :0)

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1692567.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies were flavorful and soft. The only changes I made were as follows:  1) used 1 cup butter instead of half butter and half shortening 2) increased vanilla to 1.5 teaspoons 3) used 1.5 teaspoons pumpkin pie spice instead of cinnamon and cloves I also softened the raisins in warm water while I was measuring/mixing the other ingredients as other reviewers recommended. Cooked for 10 minutes for a golden colour but soft cookie.  My family loved these and I love that the cookies are soft, but since everyone eats so many of them, I will reduce the sugar next time. Since the raisins are sweet themselves, I think the sugars could be reduced by a third and the cookie would still be satisfying (and not healthfood-like). Thanks for sharing the fantastic recipe, Beth!

Cookie Perfection.  Doubled this exact recipe, I made the cookies jumbo size using a muffin scoop and used dried cranberries, cherries and blueberries in place of raisens and added white chocolate chips. The time had to be upped to 16-18 minnutes in my oven due to the JUMBO size. TRY IT!
