text:
2,460 people can't be wrong! I tried this recipe last night with slight adjustments per others reviews: -    1. Increased cinnamon to 2 tsp.  2. Added 1/2 tsp of nutmeg.  3. Added 1/2 tsp of ground ginger.  4. Added 1/2 cup of chopped walnuts.  5. Decreased shortening to 1/4 cup.    I chilled dough in fridge for 2 hours, scooped them with in between 2 melon ballers instead of the bigger ice cream scoop for more uniform, smaller and cuter cookies and baked mine for exactly 10 minutes.     These little wonders came out as highly aromatic... perfectly chewy and best of all... very flavourful cute cookies! They stand tall and don’t fall flat at all upon baking and I shall post my photo later…    KUDOS! A VERY BIG THANK YOU FOR RECIPE SUBMITTER AND THOSE TOP REVIEWERS!!!

text:
This is a great recipe and heres a few tips. 1. I didnt want to use cloves so I didnt, no biggie, recipe still works. 2. I didnt have any butter flavored crisco, no biggie, substituted regular crisco in place of butter flavor, recipe still works.  Also used the recommended about of real butter. 3. I refridgerated the dough before cooking 4.  Theres a review on the first page from someone that ended up with cookies that fell apart, that almost caused me to question the baking time. DONT.  If you follow the recipe, and chill the dough, 10-11 minutes is plenty of time.  You really dont need these cookies browned. 5. I use insulated cookie sheets, for me, these always turn out the best cookies without burning the bottoms.

text:
I have not made these yet but wanted to respond to Jamiesd. Yes, using all butter instead of half butter, half shortening would cause the cookies to flatten. Butter melts at a lower temperature than shortening and does not provide the same structure and body. Better luck next time!

This recipe made 52 cookies using TABLESPOONS (some rounded, some not so rounded) in case anyone needs that info. With that said, these were delicious, but not exactly what I call the best ever. text:
As other readers suggested I went on and added the nutmeg and ginger to give it a more holiday spice.  Have made them both ways and great with just the cloves too.    Also, because I have high cholesterol, I substituted (in place of the butter and butter flavored shortning) 8 TBSP's of Smart Balance.  This significantly lowered the amount of cholesterol and eliminated any trans fats that would be incorporated by using the butter and shortning.  Cut the cooking time by two minutes and they turn out just fine.    My 2 yr old loves these!!   I'm going to try replacing the sugars with Splenda substitutes for the white and brown sugars next time around.  Maybe if I'm lucky it won't take away from the great taste of this cookie.  Then they will be heart healthy and diabetic friendly ...

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed this recipe exactly and had the same problem many others had; the cookies turned out very flat.  My uncle (pastry chef) solved this problem for me.  My baking soda and flour were older than 6 mos. old.  I hadn't even considered that.  So, anyone else who had this problem try new baking soda and flour and they will come out normal; you don't need to change anything about the recipe.  I will say that although the first batch was flat and fell apart, my husband and all of our kids loved the taste....they were gone that evening.  Great taste and texture.

text:
The taste if wonderful, but I can't get these off the cookie sheet as a cookie!!  I have a ton of wonderful tasting crumbs.  I refrigerated the dough thinking maybe I had let the butter get too soft, but that hasn't helped.  UPDATE: I found success!  IF YOUR COOKIES CRUMBLE: I finally finished off the dough by dropping the chilled dough by a scant tablespoon into mini-petite no-stick muffin tins (the ones that each cup holds about a tablespoon of batter).  I baked them the recommended time and they came out as mini-petite muffins.

None
text:
These are great! I must say that I have made a few changes, though. In place of the regular brown sugar I used Splenda brown sugar. Trust me it does not taste any different. Every little bit helps, right? Also I have added some nutmeg and allspice as well as the cinnamon it calls for. I think this adds a great depth of flavor. And finally instead of raisins I have added Craisins and white chocolate chips. I will try them with raisins next time though, because I am sure it will be fantastic. Take the advice from other reviewers and bake them for 9-10 minutes max. They are soft and chewy and really to-die-for good! Thanks Beth for such a fantastic recipe!

I gave this a four star rating because there are a few tweaks that will greatly improve these.  First, just use a cup of butter and omit the shortening for a chewy but cooked texture.  Also, I'm going to omit the white sugar and maybe even cut back to 3/4 c of brown sugar because they are just too sweet.  And finally, maybe at a pinch (1/8 tsp) of nutmeg.  Otherwise very, very good base recipe.

text:
The reviews for this cookie got me really pumped up and I went straight to my kitchen and made them. But.... ugh! They are defiantly not as spectacular as the reviews made them out to be :-(  They are really missing that pizzaz everyone claims they have. The good thing about these is that they have a nice after taste... I also found I needed to cook them for 15 to 20 min as opposed to 10 to 12 but it might just be a preference thing. Also I regret not putting in more cloves (and I only "regret" it because I probably wont use this recipe again.) My advice: use a different recipe. Happy cooking!

I am certain this is the recipe on the oatmeal canister except for the substitution of 1/2 c shortening for the butter, and the addition of the cloves (which I LOVE - the smell and the taste!). https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a pretty good cookie, but not a great cookie. I followed the directions exactly, and ended with tons of wonderful crunchy but still moist cookies. The problem is that the flavor is a little confused. The oat flavor is muted; the cloves stands out front and center; the raisins, cinnamon, and vanilla are well balanced. For an oatmeal raisin cookie I want the oatmeal and the raisins to be fighting for prominence, not the cloves. I could accept the spiciness of the cloves more if there was a complexity to it such as happens in curry or in pumpkin pie. Some reviewers have suggested adding ginger, allspice, nutmeg, cardamom, etc. to spice it up and I think that has the potential to turn this from good to great.

text:
Ive been hunting for an Oatmeal Raisin Cookie recipe for ages and they have never measured up before but this recipe is gorgeous. 
My only modifications, even by accident were to use Self-raising flour (Im in the UK and didnt realise that All-Purpose Flour meant Plain!!) and I added a teaspoon of mixed spice as I like them with a strong taste. 
They turned out lovely though and I think using Self Raising flour gave them a lovely light texture.
Now Ive got to try and save some for when the children get home from school, and not munch on them all myself!

text:
I used turbinado sugar as a substitute and reduced down to 1/2 C butter without shortening.  I also used other members reviews and added 1/2 tsp more cinnamon, 1/2 tsp nutmeg and 1/2 tsp ground ginger.  I dropped the bake time down to 8 minutes and I added 1/2 C more oats.  The cookies turned out beautifully and tasted very delicious!

text:
I know that everyone and thier mother has reviewed this recipe, but I can't help it. It was just so very good. I subbed 1/2 cup ground flax seeds for 1/2 cup of the flour to boost nutritional content (and somehow make it ok that I ate EIGHT cookies throughout the day that I baked these!!) & dropped the white sugar for a squeeze of honey. Although I made a few changes it was nothing too drastic that altered the "flavor" so I feel like I can say that this is the very best recipe for oatmeal cookies EVER!(you might get tired of reading it, but...)
Thank you so much for this recipe, Beth!

text:
I am so glad I found this recipe... again!  I made these about a week ago froze the dough in a cookie roll (I wrap it in wax paper so it doesn't stick, and then plastic wrap).  Tonight I needed something quick for desert so I baked a batch.  I don't know if they got better over time, or if I ate too much cookie dough to notice how good they were the day I made them, but they are awesome!  So I have been frantically searching my Allrecipes recipe box so I could tag this one.  The only thing I did different was to substitute 2 cups of semi-sweet chocolate chips for the raisins. Definitely a keeper!

text:
This is the best Oatmeal Raisin cookie recipe I have tried (and I've tried many)with a few adjustments. I used only butter instead of the shortening. I replaced 1 cup of white flour with whole wheat flour and used only brown sugar. I also soaked the raisins in hot water to plump, and added some butterscotch chips.I had a ripe banana, so I mashed it up and added that too.They turned out fabulous. I will definately make these cookies again.

text:
Fantastic recipe.  The cookies were very flavorful, not overly sweet and super moist.  I did make a couple of changes though.  First, I used 1 cup butter in lieu of shortening.  I also substituted whole wheat flour for the all purpose flour. Finally, I did not have any cloves so I used a mixture of nutmeg and ginger instead.  Baked for exactly 10 minutes and these were perfect.  My family loved these.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe seems to have been given a bad rap.  It is really quite good and easy.  I did however use only butter because I hate crisco in cookies.  I also think that they cloves were a little strong for my taste and I will likely cut them back next time and try a little nutmeg.  Just don't walk away from these cookies!  They must be taken out when the edges begin to look done.  They will NOT look done in the middle on top.  Don't worry about that.  They continue to cook once out of the oven if left on the cookie sheet.  Let them set there until cool and they will be perfect!  the three dozen I got from this recipe were gone in TWO DAYS!

text:
Be sure to soak the raisins in hot water beforehand! I had no idea they would make such a difference...the cookie was moist and the raisins plump not dry like usual. 

I didn't have any allspice so I added an extra 1/2 t cinnamon, 1/4 t ginger and 1/2 t nutmeg...the cookies came out perfectly flavored!

This cookies are delicious, chewy and very tasty.  
I made some changes to avoid some grease: i only added one tbsp butter, no shortening because is grease. It turned out great!!!
Nice dessert for any ocassion.

This cookie is truly amazing even though I changed all the ingredients in the title. My kids were asking for choc chip cookies but I wanted to try this recipe. So we compromised. Took out all the spices and raisins and used choc chips and milk chocolate chunks. Kept all the other ingredients the same. They were crunchy on the outside and soft insides and sweetness was just right. I made 41 big fat cookies and it took me about 15 minutes to cook. Thank you Beth for sharing.

text:
I have made these twice now.  The first time I used all butter and they were nice and soft and very chewy (only leave in the oven for 9-10 minutes at the most)and delicious!!  The 2nd time I made them I took the other's advice and omitted the cloves for all spice added extra cinnamon and used a 1/4 cup butter flavored shortning because I was a 1/4 short on butter and the cookies were totally melt-in-your-mouth delicious!!  I think the 1/4 butter flavored shortning made the difference in the melty-ness and buttery flavor!  I will continue to use this recipe over and over again...it's a winner!

None
text:
WOW! These are amazing! After reading some of the reviews about cookies breaking apart I decided to let them cool almost entirely before transferring them to a wire rack. My cookies are intact and absolutely delicious! I had to substitute gluten free flours, used Bob's Red Mill gluten free Oats and added one teaspoon of Xantham Gum. Perfect! It's been years since I have had an oatmeal cookie and these were better than any I ever used to make (I worked in a bakery!). Like other reviewers, the aroma that fills your house is so pleasing. Put them in an air tight container fast after they are completely cooled or you run the risk of eating them all!

Next time I make these I am going to try to add just a bit more flour, maybe a half a cup, just to give them more body. But if you want a chewy, flavorful, complex oat cookie this is the recipe for you.

So glad I finally just looked up the best! Great job, Beth, loved the recipe! These were a big hit, as you can see from above reviews. I did bake mine on parchment paper and just removed the paper to a cooling surface (top of washer), not removing the cookies until they were completely cool, and this eliminated the "fall apart" problem I saw mentioned above- I've had that prob before! I was able to re-use two sheets through the entire recipe so the cost was minimal. text:
I've made this recipe a few times now.  These cookies are delicious!!  I might leave the cloves out next time to see what they taste like without them.  Also, the dough should be relatively cold.  I let it sit on the counter for a while and the cookies went flat because the butter/shortening had melted too much. I put the dough in the fridge for a while and the rest of the batch held up fine.  11 minutes was right for my oven.

text:
great oatmeal cookie.  I did make a few changes.  First used splenda instead of white sugar to cut the sugar amount (used the brown sugar as stated). I also accidently used nutmeg (thought I grabbed cinnemon)- still added cinemon and it was good.  Also had no raisins only cran mix (nuts/cran/choc) and the cookies were still good.  I only baked for 8 minutes.  I think this is a cookie that you really can't screw up. Added Notes... I love these cookies make them all the time as the recipe states, but wanted to try to slim down the fat and sugar...and it works pretty well.  reduced the butter to about 1/3 cup and 1/2 cup+ appelsauce.  Did a loose cup of brown suger with two big spoonfuls of honey. Added some ground ginger and nutmeg to compensate for the less sugar..they are great.  The cookies should cook 10 minutes. They are obviously not the original DELISH cookies, but for the kids they are GREAT..

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My Mom and I have been baking this exact recipe for over 60 years - they are excellent cookies and everyone always asks for the recipe. If you want to make these cookies absolutely incredible, make a frosting and put it between two cookies. In a mixer combine 1 box of confectioners sugar, 1 tsp of vanilla or almond extract, 1/4 tsp of salt, 3 tbl of melted margerine, and add milk until you get the desired consistency. Be sure the cookies have cooled or the filing will run off. Preparing these cookies this way will make them unfogettable. Be SURE you don't overcook the cookies. Just a tad brown around the edge will do. And place a piece of parchment paper on your cookie sheet before the dough. That way you can just slide them off instead of deforming them when they are done. I promise these will be the best cookies your family ever had. If you don't like raisins as some of my family does, just leave them out. YUM!

This is a GREAT cookie.  I added one cup corn flakes, crushed.  I measured one cup of flakes, put them in a storage ziploc bag and crushed them unitil they were about the size of oatmeal.This made them a little crunchier.  You could use any flake cereal.  I have tried it with a little more flakes, which made them even crunchier.

These cookies were perfect although I did make a few changes. I added 1/2 tsp ginger, 1/2 tsp ground cloves and 1/2 tsp all spice and also used 1 cup of butter instead of the shortening. I also soaked my raisins in water for a couple minutes before I put them into the cookies. They were very soft but still held their shape and I had my family wandering in and out of the kitchen because of the aroma. This was a definate crowd pleaser.

text:
My husband said he didn't like oatmeal raisin cookies - but when I snuck these in his lunchbox, he came home and told me he loved "those cookies". Little did he know...

This is a great recipe. I am a health nut and don't use any refined flours or sugars, so I substitued whole wheat flour for the white stuff and used sucanat (evaporated & dried sugar cane juice - you can find it in your local health food store or natural market) in place of the sugar. I stayed true to the rest of the recipe and the cookies turned out awesome.

text:
My boyfriend and I baked these cookies and he really loved them.  The flavor of the spices with the raisins is terrific.  But I personally prefer a thicker, chewier cookie.  These were still chewy and good, but pretty thin.  I ate mine with some ice cream, which was really good - they'd probably make good ice cream sandwiches!  I baked on parchment for 10 minutes and then checked them.  They were still WAY too gooey in the middle so I left them in just another minute and that little time did the trick.  They stayed chewy the whole week that they lasted between my guy and me!  I'll be making these again, upon his request.

text:
These are delicious.  I was looking for a good cookie recipe (not chocolate or PB...needed something different!) and these looked like 'it'.  I started making the recipe purely as it appeared--I used both butter and Crisco, while I am normally just a Crisco for cookies person.  But, then  I decided to melt the butter...per suggestions, for chewiness...and then I added an extra 1/2 tsp of cinnamon and a 1/4 tsp of nutmeg, just for fun...and a tbsp of molasses, to darken and moisten just a tad.  The turned out great--not too much spreading at all, chewy, good texture, nice flavor.  I got about 3 doz exactly--although the recipe should specify just how much picking in the batter you MUST do...!  I added more than 1 cup of raisins, and next time will try walnuts or pecans, too.  Thanks!

text:
mmm, GREAT oatmeal raisin cookies!!  i substituted margarine (the lower calorie kind) for all of the shortening and refrigerated the dough for about an hour before baking because other people had complained about spreading.  well, there was no spreading here!  the cookies baked up moist and delicious in about 9 minutes.  also, i got like 50 good sized cookies out of this, so i don't know what the "36 servings" is all about (those must be huge!)  kudos to beth for something else too.  i LOVE burnt-bottomed cookies and always purposefully "overcook" a tray or two for my own personal enjoyment. :)  anyway, with these cookies, the soft (NOT overcooked) ones are MUCH better!  they're so moist and flavorful ... we're loving them!  so don't overcook and if you want to use all margarine, it works great -- just refrigerate the dough!

text:
These are some of the best oatmeal cookies I have ever had and I am so excited that I can make them whenever I want with this recipe! I did use all butter with this recipe (I didn't have any shortning), and they were delicious. I don't know if I'd even use shortning next time. I soaked the raisins in boiling water for about 20 minutes before adding them to the batter- which makes the raisins very plump and tender. I took these cookies into a sales meeting along with Beth's snickerdoodles and the big fat chewy chocolate chip cookies (my favorite) and the oatmeal cookies went first! Thank you so much for this great recipe.

text:
These cookies had a good flavor but were hard to deal with.

Batch 1 spread out into cookie puddles that would not hold together even when cooled. I had baked at 350 for about 15 min. 

Batch 2 baked at 375 - went from underdone to overdone in about a minute.  These don't taste good overdone.

Batch 3 also baked at 375 finally turned out right, but had to keep very close watch on them.

I thought the cookies tasted good but don't feel that they are worth the constant watching.  Seems that they have to be timed just right.

text:
Like others I used all butter. I didn't have cloves, so I just used cinnamon. The first batch were only so-so. The cookies turned out very flat and spread too much. However, I froze half the batch by dropping teaspoonfuls on a cookie sheet and when I baked those (for an extra 5 minutes), they were alot better - they baked in nice heaped rounds. 

Next time, I will try adding choc-chips instead of raisins. It's a very nice chewy cookie.

This is exactly the oatmeal cookie recipe I have been searching for. I've made at least six batches since I first discovered it. I'm not a huge fan of oatmeal cookies, but these were *really* good. They were extremely easy to make. I recommend baking them no more than 7 minutes - the cookies get crisp pretty quickly. I made the cookies very small, though, so that may have affected the bake time. My only complaint is that these cookies don't stay soft for very long - even though I put them into airtight containers while they were still warm.

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made these twice now. Once with regular flour and once with gluten-free flour and they were both excellent. The g-f batch did not suffer AT ALL. I did add a bit more spice because I liked where they were going but wanted to take them further. So instead of 1 tsp cinn, I used 1&1/2, 3/4 tsp cloves, then I also added 1 tsp nutmeg and 1/2 tsp ginger. I left out the raisins in the g-f batch because those family members don't enjoy them. I guess you could add choc chips but I am currently rebelling against the addition of the darn things into just about EVERY recipe, it seems. These cookies stand up well without the chips or raisins. They are wholesome and very tasty!
From now on I will always make these with g-f flour and then we don't have to have two separate well-marked plates of treats…something that somewhat isolates those with special needs in their diet.
Update: I no longer need to cook for g-f but now I need to cook for pre-diabetic. Sooo... I replaced half the fat with applesauce and reduced both sugars by 1/2. No icing of course. I personally don’t enjoy overly sweet cookies and I think these are WONDERFUL in this form too. Sheesh! What a versatile recipe!

text:
An excellent recipe overall.  I substituted French Vanilla extract for the plain, this added extra depth to the vanilla undertones.  I   also soaked my raisins in bourbon (rum would also be delish!) before adding to the mixture. The recipe didn't call for nuts, but I added chopped walnuts.  The oven temperature and cooking times were spot-on.  I used parchment paper on my cookie sheet and was able to easily lift the cookies by hand with no sticking.  These were by far the best oatmeal raisin cookies I've ever had.  This recipe is a keeper for sure!

text:
This recipe was pure PERFECTION!! I have finally found a Cinnamon Oatmeal Raisin Cookie that worked. I have tried many but this one was bang on. I followed it almost exactly. Only one small change. I did 1 tsp of Baking Powder instead of Baking Soda. A BIG BIG Tip:  Do NOT over stir. I didn't use a mixer at all. I did it all by hand and just stirred until it was combined. Do NOT over-stir!! I believe this is the secret to the success. My cookies came out moist, golden brown, and roundish NOT flat like all the other ones i've ever made :)  THIS IS A KEEPER FOR LIFE!!! LOL ;)

Display Name:
WALTDOUD

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used all butter since I didn't have any butter flavored shortening, also, I halved the recipe.  They are good cookies, they remind me of spice cake somewhat of which I am not a fan, but I'll definitely finish these off.  My only two observations:  Firstly, the recipe says to drop rounded teaspoonfuls, which is WAY too little, more like rounded TABLESPOONFULS.  Once I realized the error, I used the cookie scoop that I bought which is about a #40 disher which is 1.5 tablespoons (go to wikipedia and look up scoop utensil for disher sizes), and that was much more appropriate.  Secondly, for those of you having trouble with them falling apart, my guess is that they were not baked long enough.  I put in two cookie sheets, and after 12 minutes the cookies on the top rack were lightly golden and held together fine after cooling for 2 minutes then removing from the cookie sheet, but those on the middle rack wanted to bunch up and break and were still too pale, I put them back in for a couple more minutes and then they were fine.

Thumbs-up from all. Tried 3 different versions just for fun after reading about all of the revisions from everyone. (BTW...Cloves and cinnamon make the cookie, loved the flavor. ) 1. Recipe as is, but substituted butter for the shortening. Probably why mine turned out a little flat. 2. Previous + chopped pecans. Hubby LOVED, says the nuts cut the sweetness a little so you can "eat more cookies" :) and 3. Previous with nuts + chocolate chips. (Couldn't help it, just had to add chocolate) and they are awesome, but very rich. Thanks so much.

text:
I am vegan so substituted a few things but wanted to leave my review because the base of this recipe is fantastic! I used 1/3 cup Earth Balance margerine and 1/3 cup coconut oil, used organic brown/white sugars, omitted the eggs and added 1/4 cup unsweet almond milk, added a little nutmeg and ginger, and reduced the flour (whole wheat) by 1/4 cup. These were amazing, soft and chewy, wonderful recipe that can be altered without changing the taste tremendously...thanks!

text:
My whole family loved this cookie. I used all butter and they came out with a crispy outside and a chewy center. I left out the cloves (personal preference) but the cookie was not lacking flavor at all. I used large flake oats which give the cookie a hearty bite. I made larger cookies dropping about 1/4 cup of dough per cookie. You will need to bake them about 12-14 minutes if you go with the larger ones. Thanks for a wonderful recipe.

text:
Like some others, I don't use shortening, so I used all butter and they turned out great.  I also discovered I only had 2 cups of regular oatmeal, so I made up the difference with steel cut oats blended into a flour.  I figured we're eating the cookies for the oats, so using oat flour is a healthier alternative than regular flour. Husband loves these cookies, even though he normally doesn't like oatmeal.  I may use more oat and less wheat flour next time.  I also added some walnuts for added nutrition.  This is a great recipe.  Thanks Beth!

None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were delicious! I think the base recipe is probably great (and as some reviewers said, very similar to the Quaker Oats box recipe), but I did make some modifications. I used 1/2 cup of whole wheat flour in place of 1/2 a cup of the all purpose flour. I used craisins instead of raisins because I had a ton of them lying around. I also wanted to use up some chopped pecans and white chocolate chips, so I added a cup each of those. Since I'd added all this the dough got too dry, so I added 1/4 cup of applesauce. Then the dough was too wet, so I added 2 tablespoons of flax seed. Seriously yummy!!!

country:
None
text:
A 1/2 tsp of cloves sounded like way too much.  Cloves are a strong-tasting herb, and if you like it you should use it sparingly.  And I was right.  I added a little less, and the clove flavor was still way too pungent for my tastes.  If you left out the cloves, it would've been perfect.  I always use 1/2 cup of unsweetened applesauce instead of shortening to cut down on the fat, and it works great with this recipe.  Moist, chewy, yummy ... minus the cloves.  My husband agreed; next time, cloves will be left in the pantry and out of my cookies!

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:

userID:
3429311
Display Name:
Vamp1138
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
28
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made these cookies twice. The first time, I took the advice of all the reviewers and used all butter, soaked my raisins, etc. What I ended up with were thin, runny cookies that were very flimsy and too soft. This time, I followed the original instructions, but I baked them for 8 minutes. They were absolutely perfect! Just crispy enough to hold together, but not hard and crunchy. The raisins were juicy and tasty! I think the problem the first time was that by soaking the raisins, it added more moisture to the cookie, which caused it to be like a flat pancake. I also believe the smaller the "drop" the better. This made 68 cookies for me, not the 36 that the recipe states. My "drops" were just over a heaping teaspoon. One last thing...I ran out of my old fashioned oats at 2 & 1/4 cups. To make up the difference, I had two packets of maple & brown sugar instant oatmeal laying around. I put it in and OMG it worked and they were awesome! Hands-down the BEST oatmeal cookies I've ever had!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were delicious. I used all butter instead of shortening, as per other reviews. I also used 1/4 tsp. of nutmeg instead of cloves because I didn't have any on hand. I used a disher equal to 1 Tbs. and the cookies cooked in approx. 11 minutes. I also got many more cookies this way. The biggest thing to remember about oatmeal raisin cookies is that if you want them chewy they need to look a little under done on the baking sheet. I found that there was no extra liquid necessary and I was also able to add about 1/2 c. extra raisins with no adverse effects. Will definitely make these again.

text:
So very delicious and chewy :)

I used all butter! no shortening
Substituted the light brown and white sugar for all brown sugar
Substituted all purpose flour for whole wheat flour
I did not have any ground cloves so I used extra teaspoon of ground cinnamon instead

Baked for 10 mins and they were perfect :)
Make sure you drop teaspoonful!
If you make them larger the bake time will have to be changed

They were soo good and chewy
Maybe next time I will use 1/4 less cup of sugar because I thought it was sweet enough from the raisins
I also cut the raisins in half because I personally don't like large raisins

Soo Good I will definitely make it again

Thank you for the wonderful recipe :)

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2203327.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
very good.  I omitted raisins and added a little bit more oats, maybe 1/8 cup.  Try placing the cookie drops into muffin cups on the baking sheet.  I did this because I wanted to use my black metal pan and easily re-load it, but it was a very nice surprise how it kept the sizes uniform, was super easy to remove them, they had a nice brown crispy bottom (until kept in airtight container where they all became one blob) with soft top, and the cupcake cups acted like little serving plates AND kept them from sticking together during storage.  HOWEVER I made double the number of servings indicated, so mine were small and cooked exactly 8 minutes.  I used all butter, no shortening. *** Next time I made them I had no butter so I used all margarine and made them the indicated size for yielding 3 dozen.  The outcome was more of a muffin than a cookie when I made them in the muffin wraps.  More of a springy cake than the chewy cookie I had last time.  Both ways are very good, as a "muffin" I had to cook them for 12 minutes and yielded 3 dozen.

text:
I tried this recipe immediately upon running across it because of the 5 Star Ratings.  In a few reviews I read, it said to cook it only 9 minutes for a soft and chewy cookie.  I cooked them for 12 minutes and they're still too soft.  I don't particularly like the ground cloves taste which is very noticeable in the cookies, so that influenced my opinion of the overall cookie.  I definitely don't believe this cookie rates a 5 star unless you like ground cloves and undercooked cookies.  I think I'll stick with the Quaker Oats Cookies...they taste better like an Oatmeal Raisin cookie should.

Awesome cookies!  And just to comment on some previous ratings...this is NOT the same recipe that is on the quaker box.  I have that recipe in front of me (as I am using quaker oats) and there are several differences.  Mainly that there is shortening in this recipe and not in the quaker recipe at all.  The small differences really make a difference :)  Wonderful cookie!

text:
I used regular shortening instead of butter-flavored shortening, because that's all I had.  I omitted the raisins because I didn't have any.  I used 1 cup of all-purpose flour, and 1/2 cup of 100% whole wheat flour.  Very minor changes.  I make them a little bigger, using a metal ice cream scoop to put them on the cookie sheet.  And I let them cook for 13 minutes.  In my oven, that still leaves them a little raw on the inside, which is how I like to bake cookies.  I like to let them set that way.  Makes for firm but soft cookies that melt in your mouth.  For a long time I've been using the "Soft Oatmeal Cookies" recipe by Bittersweet1 on this website.  No disrespect, but this one is better.  I think I've found my main oatmeal cookie recipe.  Thanks Beth.  They were delicious, even without raisins.  It's the spices that win me over.

country:

text:
This cookie is THE reason I finally decided to sign up with this site.  I'm known in my house for being able to bake anything under the sun, EXCEPT for cookies...  Something ALWAYS goes awry when I'm making cookies, but this time was completely and amazingly different!!  

I followed the recipe almost exactly.  I really didn't mean to toy with it at all.  When I got to baking though, I had to make a couple substitutions.  I didn't have butter-flavored shortening, so I used the normal golden variety.  I didn't have cloves, but instead used allspice.  I used a "heavy hand" when adding each flavor (vanilla, cinnamon and allspice) because I'm a spice nut.  And I mistakenly doubled the baking soda, but it didn't hurt the outcome one bit, so I'll be sure to add a bit extra again next time.  Also, my oven runs really hot, so I turned the temp to about 315, and they cooked perfectly in 11-13 minutes.

THANK YOU for the amazing cookie recipe!  To the lady who's batch didn't turn out, I think it probably would have been fine if you'd kept the dough out of the fridge.  Before making cookies, I've heard it's beneficial to have room-temp ingredients, even the butter and eggs. :)

These are great. The white sugar addition makes for a crisp outside. I made, w one recipe 24 small 1 tsp sized cookies AND 6 x 4 3/4" diameter giant cookies like in the bookstores! The change I made was to sprinkle some terbanado/(or Demerrar)sugar on the tops of the large ones (it's much more granular) Great addition to dress up the tops.

DELICIOUS!!  Followed the recipe with the only exception being that I substituted 1/4 cup wheat flour for white flour so I could make it a small fraction 'healthier'.  First batch I cooked at 12 minutes and was too gooey.  Next batch I went 14 minutes and still plenty of chewiness.  Great flavor.  Will definitely be making again.  I think you should easily be able to go up to a 1/2 cup wheat flour without getting too dry or cakey

I have been looking all over for an oatmeal cookie like this!!!! I will be making the next batch for him per his request with chocolate chips instead of raisins, YUM!!!  As per reviews I soaked the raisins to plump them up. Melts in your mouth!!!!!!!

Oatmeal raisin cookies are not my favorite, but I had a request from a friend... so, when I found this recipe with so many glowing reviews, I figured it was worth a try.  I just finished the first batch... and I have to say ~ they are scrumptious!  I followed the recipe to a T... The only apprehension I had was in the formation of the cookies... the dough is VERY gooey and doesn't exactly form into a nice ball... instead I just sort of dropped clumps of dough on the cookie sheet.  Mine definitely don't resemble the photo - but instead they are thick snowballs of gooey goodness... I'm not disappointed and I doubt my friend will be either!

Have made this twice, once exactly as written and the second time adding an extra 1/2 tsp of cinnamon, an extra 1/2 tsp of vanilla and a pinch of ginger. I also add chocolate chips and use all butter. They are really good cookies, but I just find perhaps they are missing a little something, cant figure out what. Maybe I will try adding some nutmeg next. I bake them for 9 mins and cool for 2, They stay nice and soft in an airtight container. They actually taste even better the next day! Thanks for the recipe.

text:
Great cookie! Soft and tasty. I used butter in place of the shortening and took other reviewers suggestions of soaking raisins for 10 mins in hot water, adding 1/4 teaspoon of nutmeg and reducing amount of clove (reviews made me nervous but I think it would have been ok as original recipe indicated). Baked for 10 minutes and had to resist the urge to put back in the oven to bake longer as they did not look done...so happy I did not because the cookies turned out perfectly at 350 for 10 minutes. I baked 30 cookies and am freezing the remaining dough for a treat at a later date!

text:
I LOVE this recipe!  I do just 2 things a little different:  I soak the raisins in the 2 eggs and the cloves and cinnamon for up to 4 hours.  Then just add that into the creamed sugars when it calls for the eggs.(My talented neighbor's suggestion) The raisins plump up and aren't so chewey.  Also, I add 1/8 C flax seeds.  Just to throw in more nutrition.  I skipped it one time and my 14 yo boy noticed cuz he likes to chew on them.

text:
I'm giving this recipe a 5 because my husband loves them.  I also thought they were great, but I prefer a crispy cookie, while these were soft and chewy.  I wasn't sure about the cloves, so I split the batter in 2 and did cloves in one half and nutmeg in the other and they were both really good.  The clove flavor was so subtle, you could barely detect it.  I will make these again and won't be afraid to include the cloves next time.

text:
I am baking these now.  My boys (that includes my husband) are gobbling them up as fast as I'm cooking them!!!  They are SUPBERB!  As the name suggests, they ARE spicy, so if you're not into all that much spice cut back on the clove.  I used all margarine for mine.  Next time I will try 1/2 shortening as suggested. Just to see the difference, I can't imagine them being any better!!! I baked mine on parchment paper too. Hint (since I was naive about it too):  Rolled oats = old fashioned oats.  Don't use instant or quick cooking oats.

This is the perfect oatmeal raisin recipe. With oatmeal cookies I tend to overbake it or it looks like mush instead of oatmeal. The first time I follow the recipe to the T with the suggestion of soaking the raisins in warm water for 10 mins. Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:
2010-04-23T11:52:47.81

userID:
4630105
Display Name:
rachelnyc
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/361325.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think my search for a great oatmeal cookie recipe may be over! These are absolutely delicious—full of chewy, fragrant, nostalgic cinnamon-raisiny goodness.     I made them almost exactly as written, with a few minor tweaks that I think worked well: I soaked the raisins in just-boiled water for 5 minutes (this plumps them and prevents them from getting hard/dried out in the oven). I only used about 1/4tsp of the cloves but also added some powdered ginger, freshly grated nutmeg & allspice. And finally I used dark brown sugar because it's what I had on hand, along with high quality French unsalted butter + organic vegetable shortening in place of of the flavored stuff.     The only thing I might change is to add a bit more butter or shortening (or reduce the flour a bit) the next time around—these go from chewy & perfect to a bit dry rather quickly, and my best batch were the ones I took out when they looked dangerously close to underdone.    All in all, however, these were marvelous & I'll definitely be making them again!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just made these today and this will now be my go-to recipe for oatmeal raisin cookies.  Followed exactly as stated except I doubled the recipe and used 2 tsp. cinnamon and 1 tsp. pumpkin pie spice instead of the cloves, and also grated in a little fresh nutmeg since I had it.  Baked on parchment paper for about 9 minutes and they were perfect.  NOTE:  Don't try to make these too huge - my first batch I wanted really big cookies but they thinned out a little too much - keep them smaller (my perfect ones were doughballs a little smaller than a golf ball) and they stay more puffed-up.  Thanks for a yummy recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Another *awesome* cookie from Ms. Sigworth! Thank you! I was looking for an oatmeal cookie yesterday and saw Beth's name on the recipe and stopped my search. As for my review, I did not have any butter flavored shortening so I just used regular. I don't like raisins so I used about half a bag of chocolate chips (mini). As I was putting the spices in, I had an incredible urge to put in some dried cranberries (Craisins). I may try that next time, since I like to follow a new recipe exactly the first time. The cloves are good but probably not necessary so feel free to leave that out, if needed. I will save that spice for when its Christmas time and maybe use pumpkin pie spice instead. Out of the 6 or so people who ended up trying these, everyone ate several. I made them about slightly more than tablespoon size and ended up making about 4 cookie sheets of 16-20. I will be making this again very soon. I baked them until they just started to get some color on them, about 9-11 minutes. Perfect! I let them cool, then put them in a tupperware. They are still sooo moist and soft today.

Display Name:
Treyz

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic but you have to be very careful where you bake them in the oven.  I have baked these two times now and would advise you to not crowd the baking tray, push down on the blobs of cookie to spread them out a little, and only bake them on the middle rack in your oven.  9 mins works great so the bottoms dont overcook, any more than that and it will be too much.  I still found though that they were a little undercooked on the top, so after a little trial and error decided to flip them over as soon as the tray comes out of the oven and bake them for an additional 1 minute.  If anyone else has any other ideas would love to hear them.  I also added a little more spice for extra flavor.  These are great cookies that I will make all year round, not just over the holidays.

country:
None
text:
These are very good.  I scaled the recipe to make 48 cookies.  I used a tablespoon to measure out the batter and ended up making around 76 cookies, which is awesome because i burned 16 of them.  I used dark non-stick cookie sheets (do NOT butter them).  The cookies that burned on the bottom were placed on the bottom rack for 9 minutes.  So I would suggest only cooking them on the middle rack.  I used all butter and a package of vanilla pudding instead of vanilla extract.  (I was out. I tend to sub with what I have on hand).  Overall this is a good recipe, but next time I will add more spice than what is called for.

These cookies turned out awesome!!!  I did add a little extra ginger, and used golden raisins. I refrigerated my dough and rolled into 1" balls to add a little height, because the first batch in the oven did come out pretty flat.  The edges are crispy and the centers are oh so chewy and scrumptious. I am not a huge fan of oatmeal raisin cookies but I think these changed my mind!!!

text:
WOW!These cookies are OUTSTANDING! I read a few previous reviews---not sure why people had problems with the batter being runny? All I can say is I followed this recipe exactly, except for the butter-flavored shortening, as I didn't have any on hand. Instead, I, like other reviewers, used all butter. My cookies baked for 12 minutes, came out perfectly moist and chewy. The batter was not at all runny, for me. Could it be the brand name of butter? Not sure---but also, I did soak my raisins for about 10 minutes in boiling water. These are my new favorite Oatmeal Raisin cookies...thank you Beth!

text:
This recipe is delicious! I used it to make a cookie cake for my Husband. The recipe batch is too big for one cookie, so be sure to cut it back. Use only 2/3 for the large cookie. I also cooked it at the same temperature, but for 10 min. and then take it out and let it sit for a while, it will keep cooking in the center. It came out perfectly chewy and tasted so good. My only ingredient switch was to used 1/4 tsp ground cardamon, and 1/8 tsp. ground cloves.

text:
Fantastic. I have never liked oatmeal raisin cookies, but i had about a cup of raisins that seemed they would never get eaten so i decided to get rid of them in cookies. I used all butter, allspice instead of cloves, and soaked my raisins in warm water. They cooked perfectly at 9 minutes and are chewy and soft with a slightly crisp outside. Perfect sweetness, perfect spice, just perfect. And, my kids love them. Great way to incorporate oatmeal in my picky eaters diet. Thanks Beth!!

text:
I love this cookie recipe! I made them for the 4th time tonight for Family Home Evening. Kids love 'em, hubby loves 'em, and I could eat these all by myself. This recipe is great as-is or changed-up with your own add-ons, ex: nuts or different dried fruit. I've used this recipe with the dried cloves and without the dried cloves. Both are great. Going to try with craisins or dried cherries next time. Recommend that you pay attention to the cooking time. ALL OVENS are different. 10 minutes works for me, but may not for you. Happy Baking!

text:
You know, honestly i didn't really like these when i first made them. I thought they were over rated. I still kinda do, but I could attribute that partly to the fact that I didn't follow the directions exactly. They weren't bad at all, they just weren't 5 star cookies. I thought they tasted too much like breakfast cookies. But I love them now, I can't stop eating them! What I did was: Instead of half butter, half shortening, I used half "buttery spread" half peanut butter( because I like peanut butter =] ). I also added 1 ripe banana (to get rid of it) and pumpkin spice instead of cloves. I also cut out 1/4 of the brown sugar, and sprinkled white sugar on top. So, in short, I give this 4 stars, due to my disobedience, lol. But I will try this again...the right way...minus the cloves. =]

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe makes a mighty fine oatmeal cookie.  Excellent ratio of oatmeal to "regular" dough texture.  For my batch, I reduced both the white and brown sugar by half, doubled the cinnamon because I didn't have cloves, doubled the vanilla, used dark chocolate covered raisins, and added walnuts.  Very nice!  I only baked for 9 minutes.  I baked different sheets of dough at 11, 10, and 9 minutes, and the cookies that sat for 10+ minutes were very dry after cooling.  The 9 minutes cookies stayed chewy.  I will definitely try this again with cloves.

text:
I just made these cookies for my daughter's graduation party next week.  I made the recipe with margarine instead of butter to increase the fluffiness of the cookie.  I baked one dozen as a test and they did spread alot and were very thin.  I then added an additional 1/2 cup of flour to the batter.  The rest of the batch was perfect - thick, chewy cookies!  PS-I also increased the cinnamon to 1 1/2 tsp and added 1 tsp of baking powder.  Next time I will decrease the salt to 1/4 tsp.

text:
After hearing all the wonderful reviews on this cookie I thought it would be an instant favorite. I was disappointed though. The overall flavour of the cookie was ok, but I think the use of shortening really ruined it for me. The cookies tasted like something I would have bought at a grocery store bakery - very mass-produced and cheap tasting, not at all like a homemade cookie. I would possibly try again with real butter, but will probably just stick to my old basic oatmeal cookie recipe and modify it accordingly.

text:
I followed the recipe with the exception of substituting all butter vs. butter and shortening because I had no shortening in the house.  I thought they tasted great but fell apart on the cookie rack, so I added a little more flour maybe up to 1/2 cup to what batter was left and they held together better and still tasted great.  If you are making these with all butter, I would add a bit more flour.

text:
I've made this twice, and if I remember correctly, the last time went smoothly. This time I must have messed up because the batter runs everywhere so that I get nothing but a wafer-thin mess at the end. The only thing I did differently this time was soak the raisins (i also use dried cranberries) in warm water first, as another reviewer suggested. If this plumped them, I don't know and don't care. I think either the added moisture (I did drain and pat dry, but still...) made the batter too runny, or else the warmth melted the butter. Either way, of the 36 cookies this was supposed to make, I have only two that are still in a recognizable cookie shape. They still taste lovely, though.

text:
Fantastic recipe!  If you have instant oatmeal on hand like I did, six packets will equal the three cups of rolled oats required; just cut the sugar by about a quarter cup otherwise they can get wicked-sweet due to the flavoring in the instant.  I used Quaker's 'Holiday Spice' but you could surely use Maple & Brown Sugar, Apples & Cinnamon or Regular Flavor...probably a couple other varieties, too!  They turn out a little flatter/chewier with the instant oatmeal but the cookie eaters in this house seem to dig that. ;)
Review:

userID:
2548604
Display Name:
Jayme

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm so happy I found this recipe again! I made these last year and they were so good. I wanted to make them for a Christmas party this year, and I must have forgotten to add them to my recipe box. I'm thrilled I found the recipe again, and made sure to add it. I do make some changes. I use unsweetened applesauce instead of butter or shortening to make them healthier. I don't care for cloves, so I substitute that for allspice. I also increase the cinnamon to 1 1/2 tsp, and add 1/2 tsp nutmeg, 1/4 tsp ginger, and 1/4 tsp pumpkin pie spice to make it just a little bit spicier. But these changes are not enough in my opinion to take away from a 5 star rating, since they are more due to preference and not due to a bad recipe. Last year I used golden raisins because that's what I had, and this year I used regular. Both are delicious. I lined my pans with foil for easy clean up, and 10 minutes in my gas oven was perfect for cookies that are just slightly cake-like, with just a hint of crispness. These are fabulous and I will keep this recipe to make again and again.

text:
This was a good recipe to start, but I made a few modifications.  I found that it was a little bit too dry, so I cut back the oats to 2 cups and added another 1/4 cup of milk.  Also, I skipped the granulated sugar as it was already very sweet with just the brown sugar.  Lastly, I used whole wheat flour instead of the enriched white flour because it was what I had at home and it turned out well.  For the first batch, I made the cookies a little too big (about 2" or so in diameter), so I had to adjust the cooking time to 15 minutes and they turned out perfect.  I would make this again.

text:
UPDATE: I never got around to mailing these to my friend (I was sick), so I brought them to work for our cookie exchange. Everyone liked them. I thought they lost a bit of their chewiness (but they were still good - and they smelled divine!). I didn't try warming them in the microwave... I'll have to do that next time! These are good cookies! Oatmeal raisin is not my "favorite" cookie (mine is chocolate chip), but these were yummy : ) Made half a batch to ship to a friend for Chirstmas. I used a 3 T Pampered Chef scoop for all of my cookies (and they were just the right size!). I think I made a little less than 1 1/2 dozen because of this.... I also had to bake my cookies for about 13 - 14 minutes because they were large. Note to all: these cookies smell WONDERFUL!!!  They are very spicy (in a "warm" sense, kinda like gingerbread). I followed the directions to a T, but next time I make a batch, I'll add 1 c. of raisins as a 1/2 c. just wasn't enough (I like raisins in every bite!). I think subbing chocolate covered raisins (i.e. Raisinettes) would be delicious and I might try that instead. I'll have to see how these are tomorrow. I am hoping for a soft, slightly crispy cookie to mail out this week. Thanks for sharing!

text:
OMG....this cookie is exceptional!  It's exceptional bc it's so :

a) EASY
This is the first time I made it, and it only took 30 mins to make.  It was so effortless and yet, the cookies turned out like they came from a gourmet bakery.

b) VERSATILE
I added a various of spices that was not on the original recipe list.  I added more cloves, more cinnamon, some nutmeg, a bit of allspice and it really packed the flavour.  It was goooooddd.  I also added a bit of rum to the batter for a bit of a kick and moisture.

c) FLAVOURFUL
Such easy ingredients, but so much flavour.  It was also very moist and delicious.  It stored so well!

text:
These were great.  I was a little leery of using a full 1/2 tsp of cloves, but it was just right.  In later batches, I have added another 1/2 tsp of cinnamon, 1/2 tsp of nutmeg and 1/2 tsp of ginger for a spicier cookie.  We tend to leave out the raisins, but we did add Craisins to the last half of a batch.  Very good!

text:
I would like to give Beth credit for this "perfect" recipe, but I'm afraid the ribbon goes to Quaker Oatmeal!  With the exception of the extra lard and crushed cloves (ewe), this recipe is IDENTICAL to the recipe on the underside of the oatmeal lid.  Oh, a quick note...if you like your cookies chewy, try increasing the brown sugar and decreasing the flour and oats from 1/4 to 1/2 cup!  Then you have the "perfect" CHEWY oatmeal cookie!  =  )

None
text:
Omg!  These are soooo delicious!  I made some healthy modifications as I always try to do when baking.  I reduced the butter to 5 Tbsp instead of 8 Tbsp.  I used Splenda sugar blend in place of the white sugar. I also substituted 1/2 cup of the flour with wheat bran.  The oats mask the taste of the bran, and you get the added fiber while using less white flour.  I also added butterscotch chips as an extra treat...these are really divine!

text:
This is the first time I have ever made oatmeal raisin cookies. They were pretty good; they would have been spectacular if I had copied the recipe down correctly. I don't know how I did it, but I wrote down 1 cup of butter instead of half butter, half shortening. As a result, they turned out a bit dry. I also didn't have any cloves so I left them out. I didn't think I would miss it but I really did! I will definitely make this one again after I get some cloves. Without them, I was thinking that some flaked coconut might have been good in these. Don't know how it would work with the cloves, though. Thanks for the recipe!

These are absolutely the best cookies ever. I have even made changes to suit my families taste and they are still superb. I've added pecans or walnuts, chocolate chips, m & m's, whatever my kids want at the time. They are pure heaven. I too use real butter but I use the butter flavored crisco packs. Twelve minutes are perfect cooking time in my oven and they stay chewy for days, I spoon them out in a tablespoon and they plump up to be perfect size and shape. Awesome recipe Beth. text:
Great cookies. I changed a bit but used this as a base. I doubled the recipe and used Kamut and Prairie Gold wheat combo freshly ground in my mill (yum). I also used 1 cup of butter and 1 cup of applesauce instead of the shortning. Used all the brown sugar and used half raw organic sugar for the white. I also added about 3/4 of a cup of pecans for an extra crunch. I baked them about 15 minutes since the applesauce makes the batter wet. The are a huge hit. Thanks for the recipe.

text:
Doubled the cinnamon and cloves and used Smart Balance spread instead of butter, otherwise followed recipe exactly. These were very easy to make cookies. Baked for exactly ten minutes and this was enough and perhaps a minute or two more than necessary. Mixture was runny and I was worried about that but it made decent if thin, light cookies that are relatively low in fat and not too sweet.  They were just a bit dry, but that may be because I did overbake them by a minute or two. Gave them a 4 because I've had better cookies but these were okay and really quick and easy to make.

This recipe yielded a delicious oatmeal raisin cookie, however I was quite disappointed with the outcome. I expected the spices of the cookie to have a significant kick - I found otherwise. I continuously sampled the dough and found that it wasn't remotely spicy - so I more than doubled the spices, added ginger, and even pepper. (Also, to get plump raisins, I soaked them in hot water for about 10 minutes) The end result was a delicious oatmeal raisin cookie - but it wasn't spicy as I expected. Having noted my personal disappointment, my family and friends did fawn over the cookie.

text:
These were great! They were incredibly easy to make (perfect for me) and came out a little crispy on the outside, chewy on the inside shortly after cooling.  After keeping overnight in an airtight container, they are nice and chewy today (but lost the exterior crisp).  I didn't think they were necessarily spicy, next time I might add some more spices to get that effect. But they are yummy, easy and I will make again! I used all butter instead of shortening, baked about 11 minutes and they came out perfect.  This is basically the same recipe on the box of Quaker Oats though, which also calls for all butter (no shortening) and omits the cloves (but I am glad I included the cloves).
Also I only had light brown sugar on hand to use, but I think that worked just fine.

text:
If you like oatmeal cookies, this is THE recipe!  I experimented with different times, and every batch came out a little bit different. 8 minutes was the minimum and 10 minutes was the maximum.  Any less or more and they either came out under-cooked (fell apart) or burned on the bottom.  Took one reviewer's advice and put dough in refrigerator for 30 minutes before oven.  The first batch (cold from fridge) definitely came out the best. Made my home smell great!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make oatmeal cookies all the time, and these are one of my favorites.  I can easily make them chewy or crunchy; whichever I feel like.  I always cut either the butter or shortening in half, cut either the brown or white sugar in half, and double the spices!  I also soak my raisins in some warm water for a few minutes before mixing it in.  From my experience with this recipe, the dough balls don't flatten out much when you bake them, so I flatten out my teaspoonful balls of dough before baking to get the round, flat chewy cookies.  Otherwise they come out as chewy mounds of cookies (not bad either, just not as pretty).

I thought that this recipe was good but not AMAZING.  I had such high hopes based on the ratings but I didn't think they were as sweet as they should have been.  To be honest though, I doubled the recipe and I didn't have quite enough brown sugar so the error was most definately my fault.  I will try the recipe again and see how it turns out.  Also I used Tablespoon to drop the cookies vs. a teaspoon.  I thought using a teaspoon made them too small and hard when finished.  Update... I tried again w/ the right amount of everything and they turned out great!  The only thing I did do different is I used rounded Tablespoons vs. teaspoons and I flattened them out just a tad w/ a fork prior to baking.  They are great!!  Just what I expected.  Plus I still got 36 cookies out of the recipe using Tbl drops vs. tsp drops

text:
VERY good recipe!  My first attempt at making a different oatmeal raisin cookie was a failure, but these were very good.  They came out nice and chewy and had the perfect amount of raisins in them.  I might add just a bit less clove next time but I really did like the spiciness that it gives the cookie along with the cinnamon.  I made these as a part of my holiday baking line-up and I made things even easier by mixing all of the dry ingredients (besides the sugars) together in a large zip top bag a couple days in advance.  When I went to make the cookies all I had to do was cream the butter, sugars, eggs and vanilla then stir in the dry mix and bake.  Thank's for the recipe!

text:
I'm a huge fan of oatmeal cookies and these are the best.  I advise you not to change a thing because they're perfect the way they are.  Having said that, I did change a couple of things.  My personal preference is more cinnamon so I added just a little more.  I soaked the raisins in hot water for ten minutes and then drained and dried them before adding them to the batter.  The last thing I changed was I baked them for 10 minutes because I have an old cranky oven.  This is my favorite recipe for oatmeal cookies.

text:
First of all, I read most of the reviews, the good and bad.
I read how people said it was basically the same recipe off the Quaker box, so I figured it would be fool proof. To me, the success of a recipe depends on how fool proof it is.

This was my first time making oatmeal cookies, but I was short a few ingredients and had to do a couple of substitutions.

I felt there wasn't a lot of spice or even sweetness. It was a little bit bland for me.

I'm not ready to give up on this yet! I am definitely going to try this again and make sure I have all the right ingredients and no substitutions. I believe it was my own fault for this recipe not fulfilling it's full potential.

I think if you make this one time and don't like it, it's definitely worth another try.

These were good cookies; reviews helped alot!
I live in Va so we have a flour in the south called White Lily. Its a self rising soft wheat(cake flour). No messing with soda, salt etc It makes these cookies easy and tasty! I used 3/4 cup butter, cinnamon, pumpkin pie spice and cooked on convection for 10min. Next time I'll try chocolate chips.
Not the Ultimate but close.

I used margarine in place of shortening and whole wheat flour in place of the all-purpose and instead of getting 36 cookies, I managed to 52 good sized cookies.  I like the taste and the consistency, however even though I used fresh spices, I did not find these cookies to be spicy at all.  I would recommend using twice the amount of spices called for. Since discovering this recipe on here a few months ago, I have made these cookies many times.  My 4 year old LOVES them and asks me to make them all the time. Sometimes it's 3 cups, sometimes less.  These are a family favourite her, Thanks Beth :)

None
text:
Wonderful cookies!  The amazing thing is, I am not a raisin lover, and I can't stop eating these things!  I did make a few slight changes based on some of the reviews I read.  Since I'm avoiding shortening and margarine (trans fats), I used all butter in this recipe.  The cookies spread beautifully (I form each spoonful of dough into a ball before baking) and there's no substitute for the wonderful taste of real butter.  I used ground Allspice instead on cloves (not a big fan of them), which really complimented the flavor of the cookies.  And since my oven runs hot, I reduced the baking temp to 325 degrees and baked about 11 minutes, which yielded perfect, golden cookies that were chewy with a slight crispness on the edge.  Awesome cookies!  Thanks for the recipe!

Absolutely the best oatmeal raisin cookies I have ever made! Did 2 things different though. I let the raisins soak in very hot water for 1/2 hour then drained & towel dried them...and I didn't have ground cloves, so I used pumpkin pie spice. The cookies are incredibly moist and have a wonderful taste. The raisins came out plump & juicy. These cookies do not last long. I've made them for home and for work and everyone thinks I'm a wonderful cook! hehehe...Thank you Beth!

text:
Yummy! My idea of a great cookie, moist and chewy.  Used all butter, didn't have the shortening and I used dark brown sugar. I soaked the raisins in warm water and a bit of vanilla for about an hour before baking. Everything else was as recipe called.  My husband, who "doesn't like oatmeal cookies" couldn't stop eating them.  Alot of reviewers stressed not to overbake and as a result I jumped the gun and underbaked the first batch, but the next batch turned out perfect.  Thank you so much Beth, I will be making these again and again.

text:
I think my expectations for these cookies were too high.  They were really good, don't get me wrong, but I don't think they were "exceptional".  I made them a bit bigger than recommended because rounded teaspoon is very small, rounded tablespoon seemed more appropriate.  I really liked the cloves in there!  It adds such a nice surprise!  I think this will be my standard Oatmeal Cookie recipe but I think I'll doctor it up from now on, maybe more raisins (you hardly notice they're there), some chocolate chip cookies, a bit of coconut, and probably a tad bit more vanilla, maybe even some finely chopped nuts.

I am not a huge oatmeal cookie fan, but my husband is.  I have made about 5-6 different recipes and he always liked them, but he said this recipe was far greater than the others.  We could definately taste the spice from the cloves.  But I did do a few things different.  First, I made the cookies smaller, I managed to to squeeze out 5 dozen cookies.  I did have to reduce the baking time for this and I found that 8-9 minutes in a convection oven works best with the smaller ones.  Thank you so much for the great recipe, I will be making this over and over again.

text:
Really good cookies.  This recipe is very similar to the "Vanishing Oatmeal Cookies" recipe found on Quaker Oats oatmeal canisters, except for the change to butter flavored shortening and the addition of cloves.  I do not like to use shortening except to grease pans, so basically I followed the Quaker Oats recipe and added cloves.  That recipe makes the best oatmeal cookies ever, so not surprising that these are also delicious.  My boyfriend suggested that the addition of cloves make these a more "grownup" cookie.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
As everyone else has said, this is basically the same recipe on the underside of the lid of the Quaker Oats package.  My first batch came out way too flat, even though it still tasted great.  I tried again using all margarine, and 1/2 tsp of baking soda + 1/2 tsp of baking powder.  I also chilled the dough for about 5-10 minutes before putting onto the cookie sheets.  This produced a much more desirable texture.  Also ran out of brown sugar, and substituted a half cup of white sugar for the missing amount, and it still came out fine!  Tastes great!

Excellent recipe. I've already baked them twice and everyone who's tried them can't get enough of them. They have an addictive flavor. text:
These cookies are best if you do not put them in fridge before baking.  Also do not over bake them, pull them out of the oven when they are just slightly under being fully cooked.  And with any cookie, when they're done baking leave them on the cookie sheet for 5 mins before transferring to a wire rack to finish cooling.

text:
Make sure you have fresh raisins!!!! Mine were a bit old and you can taste that they are stale which is too bad. I read the reviews before I started this one like many others! The ways I differed from the recipe:
- I used all butter (as I didn't have shortening);
- I used quick oats instead of rolled oats;
- added an extra 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon;
- added 1/2 teaspoon ground nutmeg; and,
- added 1/4 teaspoon ground ginger.
Cookies turned out really well! They are a bit soft for my liking, but could be due to the all butter or oat type. The flavour of the spices are amazing!

These were quite good! Aside from subbing out the cloves for cardamom (because that’s what I had), I veganized this recipe, switching out the 1/2 cup butter and 1/2 cup shortening for 1 cup butter flavored coconut oil and the eggs for flax egg (1 tbsp ground flax seed + 3 tbsp water = 1 flax egg). Okay, now that I’ve spelled it out, I realize I changed a lot! ??????? Oh well...??????? They were delicious though. Thanks Beth!!!

text:
Yummy! Except the shortbread I never baked any cookies; so yesterday (29th Dec 2019- historic day) when my family mentioned about oat and raisin cookies, I decided to try and based on number of reviews I decided on this recipe. Since I had only 1/2 cup of golden raisins, I decided to half the recipe and decided to match the quantity of sugar with just brown sugar packed. It was great but you know when you get comments from the critique of the house ‘Wow that’s great but if you had blah blah’! So I was the one who thought it was not good decision to use all brown sugar of mentioned quantity. I added 3 teaspoons of white sugar and voila that was a ten star to the recipe! 
Lesson learnt: if you want to use only brown sugar add about 2T more than the recipe called for.
RATING: Loved it and it’s in my favourites now... do I need   to say  more.

text:
The end product after my corrections turned out amazing! I love the flavor the cloves give these cookies and it gives it a more christmasy flavor. The recipe states to bake at 350, but I found the cookies weren’t baking properly, so I turned it to 375 according to the regular oatmeal cookie recipe on the oatmeal container. I also added a couple more minutes, about 14 minutes in total to really give it the crispy outside but soft inside.

text:
I first made these cookies when my husband and I began dating because this is his favorite kind, but forgot where I found the recipe until stumbling across it now. I’d never made oatmeal raisin before, and honestly never ate them because they looked boring. In making these for my new boyfriend, I burned my arm on the oven rack but the cookies turned out great! Now we’ve been married 9 years, and I still have a burn scar on my arm and often use the line “I burned myself for you!” Thanks for a tasty recipe and wonderful contribution to our story together. :)

text:
I did make a few "adjustments", but love these! I used baking powder instead of baking soda, the cookies seem to be puffier and lighter this way. Also used craisins and nuts, as I don't care for raisins, and like nuts! Otherwise follow directions on letting them sit on the cookie sheet for a minute or two after removing from oven. Helps them "set" a little better.

None
text:
The cookies are great. I used all butter, as some have said. I also threw in a few chocolate chips that I had, and since that made the dough thicker, I added just a few drops of water. The magic time in my oven was 11 minutes, and they came out great. I found that lining my baking sheets with parchment worked better than aluminum foil, as the recipe suggested. Overall, the recipe was easy, and delicious, and I will make it again.

These are perfect! I think I might name them “spiced” instead of spicy, but they are fabulous. Word of warning: it’s best not to chill this dough. Or at least bring them to room temperature before you bake them. I’m wondering if some of the reviews about them being runny is because the dough was chilled, which was what I found to be the case.

I made these and they are AWESOME !!  May have to vary the baking time.  I also used all Becel Margarine and it worked out fine as I didn't have any extra butter on hand. I used the spices in recipe but also added 1/4 tsp allspice. The flavor blend was excellent, the texture was soft inside and a slight crisp to the edges. This is definitely a keeper as there is room for slight adjustments to your own preference. KEEPER, KEEPER, KEEPER !!  Thanks so much for sharing this recipe.

I don’t bake and I don’t cook. My husband does (he is a chief). I don’t like cookies and I don’t eat them. But my husband was out of town and I wanted to surprise him by doing something “unusual”. So, I baked. I had to wait for him to get home, so that he can tell me if cookies came out good or not. First thing he said “where did you buy them? Those are really good”. Note: I added white chip chocolate (he likes white chocolate). PS: happily married for 20 years.

text:
These cookies are just what I was hoping for!  Just the right spice and texture. I did use a little extra cinnamon and a sprinkle of nutmeg along with the cloves the recipe called for. I also plumped the raisins. After reading reviews I decided to try replacing part of the shortening/butter mixture with applesauce and I added a couple of extra tablespoons of flour hoping to prevent them from flattening out too much. It must have worked because they couldn’t have turned out better!  Baked for 13 minutes at 350. Made 5 dozen.

text:
These are excellent cookies! I halved the recipe and got 27. They are soft, chewy and a little crunchy with a nice blend of spices. I used all butter (maybe that's why they came out a little flat?). In any case, they're delicious! I also added a little more raisins, and found baking at 8-9 min worked for me. I've had several already and needed to put these in a closed container very quickly!!! UPDATE: Followed recipe using regular shortening (not butter-type). Kept in a container, they stay moist for a quite a while.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Followed recipe (almost) exactly. But my dough was way too dry, so I eye balled a splash of milk. Took forever to work it into the dough!! But ziplocked it and put in fridge overnight. (I was too tired to bake some by then). By next night the dough was perfect!! Only change was I omitted cloves (only had whole ones and I don't like anyway) but threw in a little ground ginger and a few rasps of fresh grated nutmeg!! And poached raisins in 1/2 inch water, drained, let cool then added, plus used 1/2 regular raisins. Don't remember bake times but I made huge cookies and flattened a bit before baking. And I got thick, soft, chewy cookies!! Definitely making again, with above adjustments. Still have dough left that I will freeze. No idea how that will work out though. Great base recipe!! :-)

text:
If I could give these ten stars, I would!  I made these exactly as the recipe was written EXCEPT I substituted dates for raisins because that is what I had on hand.  They were fantastic!  I will continue to use this recipe and I will also continue to use dates because my family loved these so much.  Now, a note on baking... everyone's oven is different.  I had to set my oven to 375 and cook for 15 minutes for the cookies to slightly start to brown around the edges.  The results were a soft chewy cookie with an ever so slightly crisp bottom.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I loved these cookies!  I did make a couple changes, based on what I had available and some of the reviews.  I used 1 cup of butter (no butter-flavored shortening), added 1/2 tsp nutmeg, and substituted currants for the raisins (I didn't have any raisins in my cupboard). They turned out pretty good, although just a BIT crumbly.  I would suggest to let them cool completely before moving them to an airtight storage container. Otherwise, SO EASY to make! And this recipe makes a few cookies over 3 dozen medium-sized cookies (if you measure the dough out with a tablespoon).

I love these cookies. I used all butter, and added 1/4 tsp nutmeg and 1/4 tsp allspice. They are chewy, buttery, and spicy. Perfect for Christmas time. Mine were cooked perfectly at 12 minutes. Update 2019: Still a family favorite, and the only oatmeal cookie recipe I use! I like to use dark brown sugar just to add a bit more flavor. Great recipe! Will convert any non-oatmeal-raisin-cookie lover with just one bite!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Sooooo good! My wife is an oatmeal cookie fanatic and told me these were the best she's ever had. We used 1 cup of unsalted butter instead of the butter/shortening combo but kept the rest of the recipe the same. Regarding baking time, all ovens are different and vary in temperature, and cookie size is going to vary as well, but its worth noting that our first batch took 16 minutes  before being solid enough to remove to a cooling rack without falling apart.  For the remaining batches we used the convection oven setting at 325 and they were perfect after 11 minutes, and still moist after a day. Unfortunately (for us) we made these cookies to give away and only kept a few in the house. I'll be making these again... very soon!

Display Name:
Victoria Biello

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4664065.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are quick and easy. I followed the recipe with a few small changes. I did what others recommended: soaked the raisins in warm water 10 minutes, patted dry then sprinkled them with flour. I also pulse processed the oats the 
 a few seconds. I added 1/2 cup mini chocolate morsels. I baked them on parchment paper at 300 degrees for 15 minutes as a reviewer suggested but left the second batch in for 15 min and 30 seconds since every oven is different.
They came out baked through with a perfectly chewy texture. 
I got 45 cookies dropped by rounded heaping teaspoons.
Love the slight flavor of cloves! Thank you for this great recipe!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these as a gift for a guy who gifted us with his wonderful peat moss and compost. I combined butter with shortening as called for, and added a tiny bit of real butter flavoring as suggested. I added Wheat Montana rolled oats. I presoaked the raisins as suggested. I added a half cup of small NC pecans to provide for a nice crunch. When dropped on the cookie sheet they were nice high piles of yummy goodness. While baking they went flat - totally flat, as another reviewer had experienced. I have over 40 years of baking experience and this is the second time I've incorporated shortening into a cookie recipe, both times having them go flat. In the future I will just use butter no matter what the recipe says. I still sent them as a gift because the spiced flavor is good.
