city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am very picky about my oatmeal raisin cookies. They have to have flavor - and most importantly - be soft and chewy. As long as these are not overcooked (which is easy to do if not watching closely) they are perfect. I can't keep my hands off of them! I followed the recipe exactly except I used regular shortening since that was all I had on hand. I am eager to see if the butter flavored shortening really makes a difference. All in all super tasty and easy recipe that I was able to make in no time with the help of my stand mixer. Also, on a side note, this IS NOT the same recipe that is on the quaker oats container. Yes, they are similar, but the increments  and added spices are different. The difference in the increments alone will have an impact on cookie taste and texture.

I LOVE these!! My parents wanted a healthy alternative to a chocolate chip cookie and this was it! The spices are nice and create a warm sensation that is pleasing to the taste. I normally use coconut oil in all of my homemade cookie recipes so I substituted the shortening for coconut oil in this recipe as well. I still love my chocolate chip and snicker doodle cookies but I have to admit that these are hard to beat!!

country:
None
text:
I thought these were great, but what would you expect me to say?  Except the neighbors and friends I shared them with all popped up sooner or later saying, "best cookies ever!"
I soaked the raisins, of course, and discovered that while this recipe makes a huge batch, you can put half the dough in a ziplock bag and bake them a day or two later, and the second batch is even better. (Some crazy baking powder/ baking soda reaction!). You won't go wrong with this recipe, but watch the bake time, turn the cookie sheet 180 degrees halfway through, and when the edges are slightly brown, they are done. Edit: soak the raising in rum to go to the next level!

text:
These cookies were soft and chewy even two days later (we had to exert some major self control for that to happen). I followed the recipe as is, just tossed in a few chocolate chips I had lying around and also soaked the raisins in hot water for ten minutes before adding them in. I wonder if that's part of what made the cookies so moist. About ten minutes was the perfect time for my cookies. I don't usually make great cookies, but these turned out wonderfully, I will definitely hang on to the recipe.

country:
None
text:
These are awesome!!! I don't really like raisins so I will leave them out but this last time I added a cup of white chocolate chips I just happened to have and WOW -- they were delicious!!! I'm usually not a big fan of white chocolate but it gave the cookies an additional sweetness (like the raisins would) but without adding a strong flavor. Try it!! I also use all butter and no shortening. I have noticed an issue with getting them to bake in the center so I've tried dropping the oven temperature to 300 and baking for 13-15 minutes instead. It seems to work and the cookies are not overdone. My husband LOVES these cookies so they are a keeper in our house!

country:
None
text:
I love oatmeal cookies! This recipe is my favorite by far. I followed the directions exactly,  but read enough reviews  ahead of time to have figured out that these cookies would probably spread. I put on a few as a trial batch to determine how they would bake. Mine took a little longer than directed (13 minutes) AND I waited a minute or two to let them cool before I moved them to the cooling rack. I was able to make 3 dozen cookies to give as gifts dropping them by the tablespoon. I also made a second batch the next day keeping the dough in a sealed container in the fridge. This helped with the spreading as the cookies baked but not by a lot.

userID:
2580702
Display Name:
Tammy Bahm
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
14
favoritesCount:
193
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2352624.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband wanted to smell something baking in the oven at the cabin, so I chose to make these cookies.  I didn't have any cloves so I substituted that with all spice.  I added about 1/8 of a cup of flour which helped then stay a higher cookie rather than flat.  The taste and smell are awesome.  I am not an inexperienced baker.  I bake almost everyday.  I did put the raisins in hot water to plump them up and probably added a few more than the recipe called for since we like a lot of raisins.  I did not use a mixer for these cookies which I usually do but my kitchen aid is at home not the cabin.  It was still easy enough to mix up.  I am not sure where the negative reviews come from.  I will be sure this recipe is my go to recipe for oatmeal raisin cookies.  Next time I may add some walnuts they would be even better in my opinion.  Try this recipe for yourself.  I will be making more for our Christmas cookie plates.
Review:
Rating:

text:
YUM!  I didn't have brown sugar on hand, so I substituted 1/2 cup white sugar with about 1/4 cup of dark corn syrup.  The cookies turned out a little cake-like, but that's probably because of my lack of brown sugar. They tasted AMAZING!  I like a spicy cookie, so I doubled the cinnamon and also added 1/4 teaspoon each of nutmeg, allspice, cloves and about 1/8 teaspoon ginger.  Like others, I also used 1 cup of butter instead of 1/2 butter/shortening.

text:
I've been making this recipe for years, both the way it's written and with changes. My changes are purely personal taste: one of my children doesn't like raisins, so sometimes I drop them (is it possible to make oatmeal raisin cookies without raisins?). And my husband loves cinnamon, so I usually add a lot of cinnamon. A lot. Everyone asks me for the recipe, as if it's some family secret, and I'm always happy to refer them here. This is the BEST recipe for oatmeal raisin cookies, and absolutely a necessity for an expat American in Norway who misses real American food.

text:
THESE ARE THE BEST OATMEAL COOKIES EVER!!
After reading the reviews I decided to give this recipe a try. I noticed alot of views said that this recipe is the same one as the Quaker Oats recipe. I think although it is similar, I prefer this recipe over the Quaker Oats. This one has an additional 1/4 cup of butter and additional 1/4 cup brown sugar. My cookies came out delicious, the best oatmeal cookies I have ever made. Ive tried the Quaker Oat recipe in the past and my cookies always come out cake like and puffy. This is my new oatmeal cookie recipe. Thanks for posting!!

text:
I have never made oatmeal cookies before, these were my first attempt. They turned out incredible and everyone in my house agrees that they are the best any of us has had before! I made a few changes, but only out of necessity as I was lacking certain specific ingredients. 1st I had to use bread flour as that was all I had on hand. 2nd, I only had unflavored shortening, so I used that plus a quarter teaspoon lemon extract; it should be noted that I also still used the vanilla extract in the same proportion. The last change I had to make was that I used two packages of instant rolled oats in apple cinnamon, because I only had 2 1/4 cups of plain rolled oats left in the can. Every thing else was done the same, and baked perfectly in about 11 min. Thanks so much for the recipe!

text:
Used only butter.
Added extra  1/2t cloves, 1/2t cinnamon,  1/4t nutmeg.
Soaked raisins in hot water for 10 minutes. Used the middle-sized scoop, baked for 12 minutes on the stones, then used the metal spatula so they didn't have to sit on the stones 2 minutes.
My go-to for oatmeal raisin cookies!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I loved the recipe. the only substitution i made was to use a combo of butter and unsweetened applesauce and also straight butter (no shortening) and they turned out perfect both times. For a crispy cookie, i used room temperature dough and flattened them a little. And for soft fluffy cookies, i chilled the dough for a hour and scooped them into balls and did not flatten them at all.
MOST IMPORTANT! the type of cookie sheet you use is critical. the best for any cookie is the insulated, flat polished aluminum sheets. T-fal makes the best one. do not use a non stick pan.

text:
I made this recipe originally as a gift to send my 93 yo mother since she said her favorite cookie was oatmeal raisin. Well, she loved these and raved about them and frequently requested them. I still send her a batch and they are always a hit! We love them as well. These are the most wonderful oatmeal cookie. I took a tip from another reviewer and soak my raisins in boiling water for 10 mins and then flour them. The most recent time I used a mixture of regular and golden raisins and they were terrific. Truly a marvelous recipe. Thank you so much for sharing. These cookies have brought much joy to many!

country:

text:
This recipe is great by itself, though of course after making it a few times I felt the need to try some changes.  I do use all butter (but mainly because I always have it, while I don't always have shortening).  I also use pumpkin pie spice and extra cinnamon.  The BIGGEST change I have made though is that I use a mixture of golden raisins, cranberries, and dried cherries.  I used to HATE oatmeal raisin cookies until I discovered that if I soak my dried fruit in a mixture of egg, vanilla, and the spices for at least a day before using they are extra moist and juicy and completely change the texture.  I make the cookies this way and call them "oatmeal fruit and nut cookies".  AMAZING.

Im not a huge fan of oatmeal raisin cookies but I saw another recipe for cream filled oatmeal raisin sandwich cookies and wanted to try a "well rated" recipe for the cookie part of this recipe.
I used all butter, no shortning and and baked them for about 12+ minutes. They were soft and very yummy!They didnt fall apart but I cooled them on my cutting board, not a cooling rack.
Only downfall....the batter was sooo delicious. I ate at least 4 cookies of batter. :)

text:
This is my new oatmeal cookie recipe! It's quick, and can be put into the oven right away. I scooped into balls and they only spread after baking slightly, so they were a very round, chewy cookie. 12 minutes was perfect for mine, and while still warm, they had an outer crispiness with chewy middles...however, even now after a week in ziplocks, they are still chewy and just as good! I used all butter, just because shortening is not available where I live, and I added some nutmeg because I love it.

text:
These are the best I've ever tried!  I made these exactly as written and wouldn't change a thing.  The butter/shortening mixture makes the cookies just right - not too soft and not crunchy.  I was hesitant to add the cloves because of their strong flavor but it blends in very nicely.  It doesn't dominate as I thought it might.  Just the right balance of spice.  Nicely done Beth! (BTW, other reviewers criticized this for being the same as the Quaker recipe.  It's close but it's not the same.  Beth has added cloves and substituted 1/2 the butter for shortening.  I think these changes are what makes it)

None
text:
I rate this a 4 when made according to recipe. When made with a few changes it is easily worthy of a five star rating. I made these with only butter, doubled the vanilla, doubled the cinnamon, cut the cloves in half, added a dash of nutmeg, dash of ginger, and MOST IMPORTANTLY I soaked my raisins in Sugar water to rehydrate them. Then I formed balls a little bigger than walnuts and cooked for about 11 minutes. After doing these things I found that the cookies were the best I have had in a long time. Only thing I will do differently next time is to add another 1/4 cup of raisins. 1 cup just isn't enough for this recipe.

text:
Twelve years of marriage. Twelve years of whining about oatmeal cookies. Until I tried this recipe! My husband finally has a favorite. I use all butter instead of half shortening, and all brown sugar in place of part white. We substitute butterscotch chips for the raisins too. Be sure to use softened butter, not melted (which makes the cookies not cook right), and light not dark brown sugar (which makes them burn).

Delish!  I made this for a Christmas cookie exchange party.  But I did make changes as others suggested.  1. Increased butter to 1 c and did not use shortening. 2. Decreased cinnamon to 1/2 t. 3. This is an excellent recipe. I made some mistakes though. I may have added too much clove; it was strong and if you don't want that taste try add a little less than a teaspoon. Overall they were great for a first time. AND if you go according to recipe, they make a lot of cookies so I froze two bags of the cookie mixture for a another day. Great recipe....Thanks so much Beth!

Oh my goodness!! This cookies are heaven! My husband who "doesn't like oatmeal raisen cookies" polished them over night... the whole batch. He asked me the next morning why i didnt triple the recipe! Anyway, I cooked these just until they were done so they were soft on the inside and just crisp on the outside. They bake pretty flat and crisp quickly. I did make some changes and took notes from others. I added 1 tablespoon+ of vanilla. I didn't use the cloves because we dont like the flavor and i didnt have any. I used extra cinnamon instead. They also freeze well. (just made my second batch-2 days later) Enjoy!

The oatmeal cookies are delicious!  I used 1 cup butter, only   chopped walnuts were increased to 2 cups.  

Added 1 cup yellow raisins.  Poured 1 cup hot water over raisins.  Steeped for 10 minutes.  Drained.  Dredged in 1 tablespoon flour.

These oatmeal cookies are Rock Stars!

I thought these were really good. I followed other reviewers' advice and only baked for 9 min.

I did make some substitutions:

- used 1 cup margarine
- used 1 cup flour + 1/2 cup whole wheat flour
- used Epicure Selections Chinese 5 Spice in place of cloves
- used half of the two sugars it called for

Still made a moist, delicious and not too sweet cookie at 104 calories a piece!

These were absolutely wonderful!!!!  I did not have cloves, but made up for it with cinnamon, nutmeg and ginger.  I used half butter and half homemade lard instead of butter flavored shortening.  I experimented with the time.  9 minutes were to soft to hold shape until totally cooled, but 10 minutes were perfect in color, texture and taste.  I cooked half and froze half the dough for later.

text:
If you REALLY want to make these fabulous cookies unforgettable, then roll them in cinnamon sugar before baking. A great mix is 1/2 c. raw sugar, 1/2 c. cane sugar and 3 T. saigon cinnamon. Roll them thourougly in the mixture, roll in the palms of your hands, then roll them a 2nd time, flatten each cookie between your hands & dip top of each cookie one more time! This will make these wonders jump right over the moon!

text:
I changed with this recipe a little to feel less guilty about eating my facorite cookies. I scaled it down to 24 servings and used 3/4 cup of whole wheat flour + 1/4 cup of soy flour. Also used all butter and egg beaters. They were a bit drier than I would have liked, but I blame the flour change for that.  Next time I will reduce the amount of sugar a bit and maybe use more egg beaters for moisture. The flavor was great with the spices (I added a sprinkle of ginger and a little more cinnamon), and I will certainly will try it again. Thanks for sharing!

userID:
1013472
Display Name:
JONI
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an excellent cookie.  For those who may not agree, you might be looking at a different box - mine is the old fashioned cooking oats.  Either way - these are great. NOTE:  you will have more flavorful raisins if you do this:  place the cup of raisins in a small bowl, fill with water and microwave until the water just comes to boiling.  Drain the raisins in a mesh colander and you will immediately smell the wonderful flavor that has been released and even a hint of vanilla.  I did not change any of the ingredients or quantities, however,  I did play with the size of the cookie because I have boys and they want something more than a small bite.  I used a 1/8 cup measure leveled for each cookie, and baked for  12 minutes (6 on the bottom rack and 6 on the middle rack).  If you use a silicon mat which I HIGHLY suggest, the cookies will never stick and you can let them cool on the rack completely if you want.  I left mine for 6 minutes because of the cook time.

userID:
466917
Display Name:
JOANNH13
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
39
favoritesCount:
47
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/214810.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I cut the recipe in half and made 1/2 with Splenda and the other half as per the original recipe.    For the Splenda version I added 1 tbl molasses and doubled the cinnamon to compensate for flavor.   Baked on parchment paper for 10 minutes.   Overall it was a good sugar-free cookie, but needed more modification.  It was pretty crumbly so I'm guessing it needs a little less oats and a little less flour.  Could have used a touch more butter and more cinnamon.  The lack of sugar and brown sugar always leaves things a little bland.  But not bad, so I would definitely make again with those modifications to see if I could reduce the crumble factor.   If trying with Splenda, also be sure to flatten the cookies out manually.  With Splenda, cookies don't "spread" when baking so you have to form the cookies prior to baking.  For the sugar-y version, it was very good.  I added a little nutmeg and doubled the cinnamon.  At the suggestion of other reviewers I cut the cloves in half.   Baked for 11 minutes on parchment paper.  They flatten out while cooking so you don't need to do this manually.  For both versions (sugar and Splenda) I put the dough in the freezer for about 10 minutes and it helped keep the dough from sticking.   Overall a good recipe, but not "the best cookies I've ever had" as other reviewers have touted.   I would make again if my family requested.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-09-01T14:46:10.157
helpfulCount:
0

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Outstanding oatmeal cookie. This is not a traditional thick heavy oatmeal cookie.  The batter is light and it is better to make these cookies no more than teaspoon sized as recommended.  They do burn easily but be sure to cook them through otherwise they just fall apart.  Golden brown is a good description.  Do not overdo the cloves or cinnamon, the amounts are good as this is a very light cookie.  Always gets rave reviews.

I cut the sugar way back in this recipe as I read some reviews saying it was too sweet, I used about 3/4 cup brown sugar(all I had left) and just under 1/2 cup white. I also added nutmeg, allspice and just a touch of ginger. Also my husband hates rasins so I left them out, And they turned out so good. I did change quite a bit which is why ive given 4 stars instead of 5. But it was a great base! Will use it again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The 4 stars may not be an accurate review.  I halved the recipe and used an egg replacer (son is allergic to eggs) and only had quick oats on hand.  I don't know if it's because of one or both but when the cookies came out of the oven, it didn't look quite cooked -- it didn't hold and was crumbling.  So I left it in longer and even left them on the cookie sheet.  When they completely cooled, they're actually not that bad -- cooked and crispy.  I just wanted to add this review in case someone out there is thinking of using substitutes and just know that mine did not turn out fantastically (albeit they're still edible).

text:
By far THE VERY BEST cookies!  Made a double batch with Craisins and extra spices...wonderful.  This is a great recipe to add or change things to your own preference.  I've made several types of cookies based on this recipe...even the original is great!  Thank you so much for this recipe, it is an absolute favorite in our house.  The one and only tweak from the original recipe is I only use butter, no shortening.  YUMMY and they make my house smell devine!  Thanks for this recipe!

text:
These were okay - I have to say that I haven't made oatmeal raisin cookies in a while, but I think if I were to make these again, I would increase the amount of raisins by at least 1/2 a cup (just personal preference).  The cookies didn't seem to spread and bake and instead really just sort of baked in the shape that I scooped them in.  The dough tasted nice though.  :-)

text:
What awesome cookies!  I've been trying to find a really good oatmeal cookie recipe for a while, and this one is it!  I used all butter - and I omitted the raisens (only because I didn't have any in the pantry) but these would be great with raisens, or nuts or chocolate chips!  Once thing I researched about baking cookies, is to use cool cookie sheets and to keep the batter cold.  The cookies will be fluffier instead of flattening out during baking.  This cookies rock!

text:
Instead of the shortening, I used 2/3 cup of butter and found that the cookie as it was too buttery and greasy with the full cup. It was also a little too sweet for my liking. I ended up using the full cup of brown sugar but cutting the white sugar down to 1/4 cup. Other than that, the consistency of the cookie was very nice and the taste was also pleasant. I would have added a little more cinnamon though, just because I like it to have a little more of a kick. The cookies stay moist for a at least a week.

text:
This is a great recipe. Some people said it was runny. So, I rolled the dough into balls and put them on the cookie sheet. I followed the recipe exactly and mine didn't spread out much at all. The next batch I made I shaped into "cookie shapes". These turned out perfect! However, I left them in about 3 minutes too long. Had it not been for my own personal mistake, they would have been absolutely perfect. I will try this recipe again and keep a better eye on the color as they are cooking. The smell alone made the experience worth it!

Display Name:
SWEETIE79

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4119925.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This year, I decided to make cookies for my co-workers; I'm stacking them, wrapping them in cellophane topped off with a big sparkly bow...and these were the cookies I chose to do that with!  I did have to test the recipe out first though, and I must say that this is an amazing cookie.  I followed the recipe exactly, and substituted nothing; the only thing was though, I needed really big cookies, so instead of dropping this dough by teaspoonfuls, I took a hunk of it in my palm, patted it into a ball, and baked on parchment paper for 19 minutes at 350 degrees.; I baked 6 at a time (you should have enough dough for 12 cookies this way).  After 19 minutes, when they come out, they might look a little under baked, but leave them sit for 10 minutes and they basically continue to bake on the cookie sheet (even out of the oven); they will also firm up some as well.  Your end result after taking these steps (for the giant cookies) is a soft and chewy centered cookie, that has a bit of a crispy outer...so perfect!  Thank you so very much for this recipe; I will make these over and over again; they are just too good...can't wait to give them away as gifts!

text:
Great recipe.  The half-and-half combination of butter and shortening makes for a perfect cookie that tastes very buttery but does not spread too thin or burn.  I recommend lining the baking sheet with non-stick parchment paper so you don't have to wash the sheet in between batches.  I alternated two cookie sheets covered with parchment paper, so the entire baking process only took about 40 minutes.  I didn't bother to change the parchment paper; I just brushed off the crumbs before putting on the next batch of dough.

The cookies turned out great.  The only changes I made were I used all butter - and I simmered the raisins a few minutes in water and vanilla (next time I'm going to soak them in rum or brandy).  I baked for 12 minutes and they came out a beautiful golden brown.  I had no problems taking them off the cookie sheet.  The consistency of the cookie is semi-soft center and crunchier at the edges.  Made 48 cookies dropped by a small cookie scoop.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum! I've made this twice now, the first time it didn't come out quite right. The second time I did things a little different from the recipe and per other suggestions: 1) Let the raisins soak for about  10 minutes in water. This made them so moist to bite into.  2) After using  my mixer for wet ingredients I hand mixed in dry ingredients, oats, and raisins. I keep reading over and over that over mixing some cookies and cakes makes them tough/hard. 3) I also added about an extra 1/4 tsp of pumpkin pie spice. Just a personal preference.  4) I use the small cookie scooper and pack it in there, when it wasn't, the butter melted too quickly and they became thin and crumbly. A cookie scooper is a must for just about all cookies in my book! Makes for a uniform and evenly baked batch. 5) I baked for only 8 minutes. The cookies came out perfect when the edges started to brown but the center looked gooey, almost raw. 
This is now my go to oatmeal raisin recipe!

text:
This is an excellent base recipe for oatmeal raisin cookies. The only things I changed (and this is just my taste, you can do whatever you want), replaced the 1/2 cup butter margarine with butter (I hate the artificial butter taste), put in one tablespoon of vanilla and upped the cloves to 3/4 tablespoon. Can't keep these cookies in the tin for more than 3 days, seriously.

Any negative review, you were just doing something wrong....these are the BEST COOKIES EVER! I took them home for Thanksgiving and I was asked for the recipe on 5 different occasions. The only thing I changed was use one cup of butter instead of 1/2 butter 1/2 shortening and also they are done between 9-10 minutes (no more no less!).  Also do not leave out the cloves, that is the most important ingredient!

text:
I just made this recipe this morning. I did something I haven't done sense I found this site and that is, do the recipe "as is" and before I read the reviews. There was a couple of things I did do but I don't think they changed anything too important. 1. I soaked the raisins (only because Mom always did) 2. I used a tablespoon to drop the cookies onto the parchment, and 3. I was too lazy to take my baking stone out of the oven. Baked for 12 minutes and they came out wonderful. Using a tablespoon made 33 cookies. I think that they would have been way too small for any REAL cookie lover using the teaspoon! Next time I may play around with spices just for the fun of it!! ***UPDATE*** I made these this morning, they tasted good but not great. I was going over the recipe with some friends that stopped by for left over soup and found I made a mistake. I only used 1/2c brown sugar rather than the 1c the recipe called for. That could be the difference between "good" and "great".

text:
These were good but flat. I compared this recipe to the one on the quaker oats can and the cloves are not the only difference, she adds more butter/crisco...double to be exact. Quaker calls for 2 sticks of butter while she calls for 2 sticks plus 1/2 cup crisco. So the cookies came flat.  Luckily I only baked half the dough so I added more flour, brown sugar and another egg and they came much more thick and still very good.

text:
These were GREAT!  I didn't have the butter flavored shortening, so I used all butter.  I also did not have ground cloves and when I went to the store to buy some it was $8 for a small bottle. So instead I used apple pie spice.Maybe next time I have the money I will splurge and try to get soem ground cloves and try them. After reading some reviews I also only baked mine for only 9 minutes. I also left them on the cookie sheet to cool for a few mins. before trying to move them to a wire rack because they were very soft when they came out. All in all, once my family tried the cookies I had to watch them like hawks before they ran off with the rest of them.

text:
Perfect recipe! I made it once 3 weeks ago, following the recipe "as is" with great results: soft, chewy, hint of spice...everyone at work raved. Today I made a few adjustments to suit my taste. Used dark brown sugar and reduced it to 3/4 cup, reduced white sugar to 1/3 cup. Added an extra teaspoon of vanilla and a 1/4 teaspoon cloves. Used whole rolled oats. Results may be even better! A bit more spice, a more "whole grain" cookie taste and not quite as sugary sweet. So far, the neighbors love them. Perfect with a glass of cold milk!

text:
This is a fantastic cookie!  Full of flavor and a great blend of spices.    I changed it just slightly to make it a bit healthier.  Instead of white flour, I used whole wheat flour.  I think the nutty flavor combined with the spices even better than white flour would.  I also added 1/2 tsp more cinnamon, quite by accident, but it worked out well.  I adjusted the recipe for 4 dozen instead of 3.  This created a bit of a problem as it asked for 2 3/4 eggs and I wasn't about to toss 1/4 of an egg.  So, I did use 3 eggs.  No noticeable difference.  I think I'll save this as my "go to" oatmeal raisin cookie!

region:

country:
None
text:
Very good cookies!  I didn't have buttered shortening so I used all butter like others suggested.  I added about 1/4 cup of white choc chips at my husband's request.  I tried several suggestions for the baking portion.  1) just as written (350F for 10 mins.), 2) 300F for 15 mins., 3) convection baking, 4) refrigerating the dough for 30 mins. first.  I liked the cookies baked just as written.  There was no difference in refriging the dough.  But I made sure my butter was softened, not melted or warm.  I'm not a fan of convection baking.  Those cookies were extra flat.  I have similar results with other cookies, and, as a cake decorator, don't like conv baking cakes.  Great recipe and it makes lots of dough.  I froze some for later.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
They were amazing. I cooked them for about 10 minutes and I also added a hint of ginger. After cooking we sprinkled more cloves on top for an extra kick. They are so soft!! We didn't have butter flavored shortening so we just used regular stuff, next time I might just go full butter like others. Also, I want to try them with dark brown sugar (that's all we ever buy), and lower the amount of white sugar (I think I misread the measuring cup and added too much because they were a little too sweet). Otherwise, they were incredibly easy to make and were delicious. I baked them with the 12yr old girl I'm babysitting and we had to halve the recipe because of an oatmeal shortage, and we both had fun and easy time. I think this is my new oatmeal cookie recipe forever.

text:
Very Good! Only changes made was using 1 cup butter, and no shortening. They turned out perfect - baked in a convection oven took only about 7-8 minutes. Made one batch of 12 cookies and refrigerated the rest of dough. The next day made another batch of 12 cookies and noticed less spread, since dough had been chilled. I prefer this batch at a time because hubby and I could consume the entire recipe in one day given the chance. Thanks for sharing.

I was looking for a chewy oatmeal cookie and this recipe was very good.  I had to substitute Splenda white and brown sugar because my husband is diabetic.  I found that the amount of sugar called for is too high.  I would use less sugar the next time and use more nuts, cranberries and or raisins.  Also more spices.

These are very good, they get slightly crisp on the edges but still soft and chewy in the middle, yum : ) I think this is because of the combo of regular butter, I used Safflower margarine, and shortening, good idea! I used a little more cinnamon, less clove and a dash of nutmeg to make them a tad less spicy and I used plain non hydrogenated shortening since it's hard to find non hydrogenated butter flavor shortening but next time I might add a little butter flavoring to see if it makes a difference, thanks!

There was a recipe that I used to make in high school for him that he really liked.  I made it and this recipe I found online and sent them to him to taste test.  He voted for this one hands down. text:
I made these for my husband and his co-workers, as they are his favorite.  Everyone said they were the best oatmeal raisin cookies they have ever had, and all asked what I put in them to make them so good.  My guess is that although the spices and butter-flavored shortening are minor changes from the Quaker recipe,  they create major changes in taste.  You could also substitute choc chips for raisins, spread in a pan to make a bar cookie and drizzle melted chocolate on top when they come out of the oven...very rich version, but very good.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Well, this is basically the Vanishing Oatmeal Cookie recipe on the Quaker Oats box with two changes - half of the butter was substituted with (ugh) butter-flavored Crisco and ground cloves were added. The Vanishing recipe is still our favorite.  We do not like the butter flavored Crisco.  Crisco will give you a crisper cookie and all butter will give you a chewier cookie so if crispy cookies are what you crave try 3/4 cups unsalted butter and 1/4 cup regular Crisco. I also pour a cup of boiling water over the raisins to plump them up, drain and lay on paper towels to get rid of excess moisture, and then stir into the dough.  Trust me, these cookies  won't go to waste, but we like the Vanishing all-butter recipe better.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

This is the recipe on the Quacker Oats lid, except for the cloves.  I made these without the cloves and they were excellent.  You can not over bake these cookies or they will be hard.  Pull them out of the oven even though you don't think they are done.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent as written -wonderfully spiced and a great texture!  Even though the original is great, I usually alter the recipe for my family to make them a bit healthier & they're still delicious!  I use 1/4 c olive oil in place of shortening and decrease the butter to 1/3 c.  I reduce the brown sugar to 3/4 c, which is still plenty sweet, and use 3/4 c AP flour and 3/4 c whole wheat flour.  I'm not a fan of cloves so I use 1/4 tsp allspice and 1/4 tsp ginger in place of them.  I've used raisins & craisins and both are great.  I even make lactation cookies with this recipe by adding 2 generous Tbsps flax meal and 2 generous Tbsps brewers yeast.  Love them!

text:
delish and soft.  I think I forgot the baking soda but they rose well and are moist and chewy.  watch them carefully though, my first batch burned a bit on the bottom as I kept them in when the tops didn't look done.  don't do that!  take them out and tap on the tops to see if they're done, even if they look sort of raw.  my second and third batches were perfect.  I used pumpkin pie spice, a little additional cinnamon, and golden raisins.  to get 36, I made mine larger than a teaspoon, more like a generous tablespoon, but we like them big!  thanks for sharing.

text:
I'm sure this is a 5 star recipe but i made a few changes.I saw a recipe for blueberry cookies except they came out terrible they were flat and fell apart. so i tried this one with my changes. The first, skip the raisins and add BLUEBERRIES. If defrosting berries add a few extra table spoons flour to dry mix.I also only use cinnamon as the spice and change the baking soda to 1/4 soda and 3/4 baking powder. They came out PERFECT just like blueberry muffins with out the dry bread taste.

text:
I thought this recipe was too way too salty even though I used unsalted butter. Next time I would use 1/2 the amount of salt. I used 1/2 cup of wheat germ and 1 cup of flour instead of the 1 1/2 cup of flour that the recipe called for. This made it healthier, but didn't seem to affect the chewiness. I agree with some other reviewers in that it's best to chill the dough before putting it in the oven especially if you are using all butter instead of half butter and half shortening. I got nowhere near 3 dozen cookies from this recipe, but I do like larger cookies.

text:
I loved them!!!
It takes about ten minutes to put all ingredients that you always (well, i am:)) keep on hand 2gether! And how terrific they are! And almost healthy too;) I made first batch without changing a thing (except that I only used butter as I always do). My second batch... It was unusual... I subbed vanilla protein powder for flour since I addicted to low-carb diet, BB other stuff:))) It was a little hard to work with dough and I even had to add some milk, but cookies were almost like they have to! Kinda chewy (if u ever ate high-protein bars, u know what I'm talking about), but I like this thing a lot. So, oat=complex carbs, splenda instead of sugar (well, it suppose to be sweet, right?), and a lot of protein (I Used MultiPower Formula 80 whey)... A present for my trainer:)

Rating:
5

text:
I took the advice of another reviewer and added more cinnamon, some nutmeg and some ginger.  I used King Arthur's White Whole Wheat flour (which I LOVE; I can put it in almost anything and hardly tell the difference from white flour-try it in chocolate cake!), and added extra raisins and a few tablespoons more oats.  Instead of the white/brown sugar mix, I used all white sugar and added a little molasses (I didn't measure, but it was probably close to 2 tablespoons)  We really liked them a lot, though next time I think I'll cut the sugar a little bit if I increase the raisins.

This turned out to be a very good oatmeal cookie. I made very few modifications to the recipe - I made two batches, one with chocolate chips and one with raisins and craisins. For each I added a little more than the recommended amount. I also left out the cloves because I did not have any on hand. Unlike some other reviewers, I had no issues with the baking time. Twelve minutes turned out a perfectly soft, slightly golden cookie.

This recipe was not to our liking. First of all-- it needed more spice. I suggest adding a pinch of ginger and nutmeg, in addition to the cinnamon and cloves. There is not hardly enough levening. You need 1 t baking powder and 1 t baking soda. Instead of 1 1/2 cups of flour, use 2 1/2. Honestly, if I was you, I would look for a different recipe.

text:
I'm sorry, but my husband and I did not care for these at all, and our favorite cookies are oatmeal raisin. On the advice of others I used all butter, and because I also don't like cloves I substituted nutmeg.  That is all I changed.  We each took one bite and couldn't eat them.  But I gave an extra star because I brought them to work and everyone else seemed to love them.  I gladly handed over my copy of the recipe.  I guess it was just us.  Be careful when baking these.  I burned the first batch because they didn't look done in the middle after 12 minutes.  But after only a couple more minutes in the oven they were completely burned on the bottom.  I cooked the second batch for only 12 min., and even though they still looked too soft in the center, after they set and cooled, they were perfect.  Just didn't taste the greatest for us.  My husband made me promise never to deviate from our tried and true favorite oatmeal raisin recipe again.  Lesson learned.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-04-15T21:19:59.757
helpfulCount:

These are really great cookies and I made them as written with no changes.  The entire family liked them.  I baked a few cookies a little longer to make them crispier. These were delicious, i must say they are very delicate and need extra attention to remove from the sheet, they are thin cookies. I just baked the next batch on parchment paper, easy to remove no problems with them falling apart.  I did not have cloves so i used nutmeg and it was a great substitution and i used regular crisco and not butter flavored cuz i did not have it.  Next time i will use all butter cuz i like a crispy cookie vs a chewy cookie.  If you like chewy make as is.  Hubby said they were perfect and i agree. thanks.

These cookies were excellent! Like the others the extra spices made the difference.I added 1/4 ginger and nutmeg. I also added an additional 1/2 of cinnamon. Remember to use baking butter instead of the butter with olive oil otherwise your cookies will turn out runny.

This recipe is almost the same as the one on the oatmeal box except for the fact that you add cloves, and this recipe calls for 1/2 cup more butter/shortening than does the quaker recipe.  The quaker recipe has been my fall back for YEARS and everytime I make it people love it.  Add some coconut to it to make it good.  I always put a little extra vanilla and cinnamon, but try omitting 1/2 c shortening and see if they turn out better (those who has spreading/greasy issues)

This recipe is tasty, but it doesn't really yield any serious surprises. The recipe is almost identical to the one on the back of the lid of the Quaker oatmeal I used. I also had to take the cookies out after about eight minutes. Next time I bake these I think I'm going to grease the cookie sheet -- they kind of stuck to the pan. Overall - a good recipe, but not the best.

text:
Excellent! I made a half-batch, used ½ cup margarine instead of butter and shortening, used 1/4 cup of cartoned fat-free egg substitute in place of the egg, and two snack-size boxes of raisins. Oh, and I cut the cinnamon down to about half as both my husband and daughter are allergic. It made about 20 cookies for me and they took about 14 minutes to bake. My daughter is loving them. Thanks, Beth, for a great recipe! I think I'll add some white chocolate chips and maybe some walnuts next time. :)

Fantastic!!  I love these cookies.  This is the recipe I have been waiting for.  I changed it just a little bit according to other reviewers suggestions.  I used 1 cup butter and omitted the butter shortening.  I melted the butter halfway.  I did decide to use the cloves and added some nutmeg as well.  I also used golden raisins the first time and big juicy organic raisins the second time...wonderful!  My husband loves them and by the end of the night almost half were gone.  These make about 50 cookies.  Our favorite cookies are oatmeal raisin so I think this will be a weekly thing.

favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I liked this recipe. I substituted another stick of butter for the butter-flavored shortening, and took out half a cup of the rolled oats and substituted a half cup of steel-cut oats instead.  I made them a little bigger than the recipe stated (about 1.5 inch diameter ball before baking) and baked them 15 minutes.  They came out very soft with a very nice texture on the outside and just a bit of crunch due to the steel-cut oats.  I will definitely make these again, but I may cut down on the sugar next time and use only 1.5 sticks of butter.

text:
These were excellent.  They looked beautiful, the texture was perfect and the flavor was wonderful.  I did notice that they tasted even better the next day.  I felt they could have been just a bit "spicier" for my taste, however.  The second time I made them I used an extra 1/4 tsp of cinnamon and also added 1/4 tsp of nutmeg. This second batch was more to my liking.  All in all, these were delicious cookies that were very well received by everyone I shared them with.  Be sure to make plenty of them, though, because they will go very fast!

What a great cookie! I think I should have baked them even a bit less...when they were done cooling, they were set a bit crisper than what I would have preferred. (the centers were still chewy) So when you're making these, don't be afraid to take them out of the oven when they still appear to be somewhat underdone.

text:
I've never been much of a fan of oatmeal cookies, but these might just change my mind!  I used all butter and substituted dried cranberries for raisins.  I found that rotating the cookie sheet halfway during baking time resulted in more evenly browned cookies.  I also discovered that a couple extra minutes resulted in a crisp cookie, perfect for dunking!  I was able to get 7 dozen cookies out of the recipe as is, using a 1-teaspoon cookie scoop, so I'm not sure what Beth was using.  Thanks for the post!

text:
The PERFECT oatmeal raisin cookie! I've tried different recipes, including the Quaker Oatmeal recipe, but this is by far the best! The trick to this cookie is to get the cookies out of the oven as soon as they're done. That way they will stay chewy even after they've cooled. If you wait too long to get them out they will be really crisp after they've cooled.

text:
These cookies smell heavenly when they're cooking! I did add a touch of nutmeg as well. I'm not personally a big fan of oatmeal raisin cookies, but the people that ate them really loved them! I would note that these cookies were quite crispy rather than chewy, however. Still delicious, though! I also followed some other reviewers' suggestions and chilled the dough (while making some other cookies). The cookies still turned out kind of flat, but I don't really expect oatmeal raisin cookies to be big and fluffy either. I think they were fine!

text:
Fabulous!  My son, who doesn't like oatmeal cookies, loved these.  Don't leave out the cloves... it's what makes these different from the run of the mill oatmeal cookie.  I didn't have any butter flavored shortening, so used an extra 1/4 c. butter and reduced the shortening by 1/4 c.  This has now replaced the oatmeal cookie recipe that I've been using for years.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe.  These cookies were so good the first time around, chewy and endowed with super oatmealy raisin flavor.  Not too sweet either, they smelled so delicious straight out of the oven.  The second time?  I followed the recipe straight off the page.  Not enough flavor.  It took me a while to realize what I'd done right the first time.  I'd squished the dough down flat, covered it in sarran wrap, left it out for a night without refrigeration, then baked it the next morning.  Mostly unintentional, of course, but I guess they need time to soak in their own juices.  So plan ahead.

text:
WOW! These were awesome. My husband has been craving oatmeal raisin cookies for awhile now. I thought I would try these and boy am I glad I did. I can't believe how chewy they were! Perfect! I did change up a few things. Like others I didn't use the shortening I just used two sticks of butter.  I  also didn't have the cloves in the pantry, so I tried pumpkin pie spice which has cinnamon, nutmeg, ginger and cloves. What a great taste  it gave the cookies. I also split the batch and made some of the cookies with chocolate chips too. The kids loved that. These cookies were gobbled up by my husband and kids. These are definitely a staple in our home now. Thanks Beth!!

text:
I just tried this recipe and it's da bomb! I have tried another oatmeal raisin cookie recipe, but this one is far superior. I used all butter instead of 1/2 shortening, and added nutmeg to the recipe. The cloves are a definite highlight, don't leave them out! I added about 1/2 cup extra raisins too to make it juicier. Very good consistency, and they are much better than the bakery kind! Thanks for sharing such a superb cookie recipe!

text:
I have always made the best oatmeal cookies in my family, at least that's what they say, and these are even better than the ones I have made for years!  They don't taste as good after a couple of days so I make a whole batch of dough and cook 1/2 one day and the other half a few days later.  Keep the raw dough in an airtight container in the fridge.  It is so nice to just heat the oven and 10 minutes later you have fresh cookies!  Try this recipe!!!

text:
Despite all the great reviews, I was skeptical. This recipe is exactly the same as one provided on the Quaker Oats box, with the exception of the cloves, and splitting the margarine (Quaker) into 1/2 butter and 1/2 shortening (Beth's recipe). I'm glad I forged ahead with this anyway! This IS the best recipe! The Quaker Oats one has always turned out flat and crispy--none of the yummy, rich, chewiness you get from Beth's recipe. My husband has already told me to get rid of all of the other oatmeal cookie recipes I've tried over the years. Try this one if you haven't already! It's worth it!

1.  I followed the direction exactly, but my cookies was not chewy.  They are dry.
2.  It took me about 25-30 min. to bake the cookies at 350F, using middle shelf.  I kept open the door to check if the cookies are ready after 15 min.  They were definitely not ready at 15 min.
3.  My cookies did not turn out to be very round.  
Any advise is greatly appreciated.

The yummiest oatmeal raisin cookies I've had in a long time! Want to make them yummier? Grind the cinnamon and cloves (especially the cloves) FRESH just before you mix them in... you can smell them baking from across the street! yummy yummy yummy!

I made these for some chefs as a Thank You - that shows how much they were liked!
I used regular shortening and refridgerated the dough before dropping them on the sheet pan.
